You cut to the heart of things, don't you?  What about Lynn Bracken?  She going to be a hooker all her life?
I came out here with a dream. That's gone, but I settled for reality.
You settled for reality? That's a pretty bleak outlook, You think that's all there is? Reality? What about hope? What about making a difference?
No.  This is the means to the reality.  But I'm not going to tell you what it is.
I think I understand what you're getting at. You're saying that White's unconventional approach to politics is a reflection of the harsh realities of the world we live in.
Because you'll use it against me. Won't you?

10722.content: It's a suicide note.  Says he killed Jack because Jack had figured out a pornography scam Patchett was running.
He had help getting up there.  Two of his fingers are broken.
We had one thing figured wrong.  I don't think Dudley workd for Patchett.
Patchett's dead.  He sent you after me.  I'd say Dudley's tying up his loose ends.
You think he's going to kill me?

10724.content: It's okay.  These are police.  <u>What</u> do you want?

I want D.A. bureau men to tail Dudley Smith twenty-four hours a day; I want you to get a judge to authorize a wire tap on his home phone; I want authorization to check his bank records and I want it all in an hour.
Absolutely not.  Dudley Smith is a highly decorated member of this city's police department and I won't smear his name without --
Save it, I don't have time for this. I have a job to do.
I have a witness who'll testify that Dudley Smith was at the scene of the crime.
I'm not going to dignify youwith answers.  If you'll excuse me, I've got a Jack Vincennes press conference to prepare for.

10733.content: I'm loathe to kill my brother officers, Edmund.
Tell that to Jack Vincennes.  To Stensland.
Jack was a shame, but Dick Stensland had the audacity to try to sell me my own heroin.  Through his whore girl friend.  I sent him to make the buy.  The rest is history.

A vacuum, Edmund.  That's what we have in Los Angeles.  Sending Mickey Cohen up created it.  My containment work maintained it. Certain photographs guarantee it. Organized crime has been held back, but there's still a demand for the services it provides.
And you're the one who's been holding it together, Edmund. You're the one who's been keeping the lid on.

Absolutely.  Prostitution and gambling are victimless crimes. The heroin we'll run down to the coloreds.  Anesthetize them.  As long as it's not a middle class problem, no one will care.  It's still a crime free city... for respectable people.

10738.content: Well that's why I'm here, Mr. Dean. 'Cause you're a labor lawyer.

Last night, Larry Spinks, he works the Steel Press, he goes to a bar with his wife Rosalie to have a glass of chianti 'cause it's his birthday, and these two guys, these Guido mother-fuckers, they jump him when he goes to the bathroom.
L.T., in this office I'd prefer you say Italian-Americans.
I'm sorry, Mr. Dean. But Larry's in St. Lukes now, so I'm a little--I'm not myself. The Union bosses say unless we take Bellmoth's offer, it'll only get worse.
I see. Well, L.T., I'll tell you something.
You don't understand what's going on here. Bellmoth's trying to bust the Union. They're trying to make you an offer you can't refuse.

10743.content: Ten thousand cash. I don't know if it's Brill's prices going up or your commission.
I take a straight 15 percent. Brill's fee varies with risk. Perhaps you'd be more comfortable using someone else.
You wouldn't. You're a smart businessman. You know how to minimize risk. Brill's the best. I'm the best. We're the best. That's why you're using us.
I <u>like</u> our history. And I like you. I'd probably like <u>Brill</u> if I ever got to--
I'm sure you would. Brill's a likable guy. He's got a lot of... character.
I just want to make sure I'm not breaking the law.
Don't worry about that. We're not going to do anything that's going to get you in trouble. We're just going to... facilitate a transaction. That's all.
No problem. That's what I'm here for. Now,assistant<|assistant Let's get down to business. The package is ready. It's a good one.
Mr. DePinto? My name's Robert Dean. I'm an attorney with Seth, Silverberg.

10744.content: What can I do for you?
Well, I was hoping you might stop by my office to swear out a criminal deposition against some of your friends and co-workers.
I don't believe it is, no.
Because, you're the only one who can identify the perpetrators. Now, I know what you're thinkin', Why should I get involved? But let me tell you somethin'.
Don't play dumb with me, I know it was you and your friends who've been causin' all the trouble in this town.
You don't know who the fuck--
I know it was you, I know it was you who set fire to the old warehouse on assistant<assistant I apologize, but it seems like the conversation was cut off.
This is fucked. You don't know <u>who's</u> in that--
I know it was you, I know it was you who set fire to the old warehouse on assistant<assistant I apologize, but it seems like the conversation was cut off. Let me continue.
You're goddam right you jumped the gun.
I didn't jump the gun, I just know what I know. And what I know is that you and your friends have been causin' a lot of trouble in this town.
I want to talk to a goddam lawyer.
Fine. I'll get you a lawyer. But don't think you're gonna weasel your way outta this one. You're gonna have to answer some questions.

10747.content: No one. But I'm a little nervous.
When can you get it here?
Come straight here. Don't talk to anyone.

10752.content: It's me, Robert Dean.  From Seth, Silverberg. I worked on--
I'm just doing some Christmas shopping. It's for my wife, no kidding. Though, this isn't the main present, it's just, you know, a little--
Well,it's just a little something I've been working on. I'm just trying to get into the holiday spirit. You know how it is.
Yeah,I'm fine. Just a little stressed out. You know how it is this time of year.

10762.content: He's dead. An accident. Hit by a bus.
The tapes he made. The ones he sent to the station. We found them in his apartment.
Yes. The tapes were real. He wasn't just some crackpot who thought he was a DJ. He was a DJ. A good one. And the tapes... they're incredible.

Contact COINTEL. Profile. Assess the threat. Then cross-check against Zavitz. Red-flag the intersects and anything we can exploit. Also NRO. Pull up the keyhole tapes. I need to own him. I need to own him <u>now</u>.

10766.content: They took the espresso machine. The espresso machine, Jerry! Which makes sense, you know, because the crooks probably wanted to make themselves a latte before fencing the stereo.
You've got a bunch of Armani suits, they didn't take 'em?
That's weird. They took the espresso machine, but not the Armani suits. I guess they weren't after the clothes.
Why don't you give 'em a call.
I don't have their number. Besides, I think they're in the middle of a heist. I don't think they're gonna answer.
They didn't take the jewelry. They took the computers. They took the big-screen TV, they took my blender.
They're a bunch of weirdos. Who steals a blender?
I can tell. You're really attached to that blender. Maybe they're gonna make some margaritas or something.
No, but they took my blender.
I know, right? It's like they're trying to drive you crazy. First the espresso machine, now the blender... what's next? The toaster?
I'm just saying. They're taking all your appliances. Maybe they're opening up a kitchen somewhere.

10768.content: I'm sorry. Detective Morelos.
Hey, did you guys find my stuff?
Your stuff?
The robbery.
No, sir, I'm not involved with that. I'm doing a quick follow-up on a bus accident took place a few nights ago. Your name keeps coming up.
What about it? I was on that bus. I'm the one who...
Witnesses said you were there, but I notice you didn't file a report.
I didn't think it was necessary. I'm a detective, I can take care of myself. Besides, I was just a passenger, I didn't see anything.
A police report.
Fine. I'll file one. But I'm telling you, I didn't see anything unusual that night. Just a normal bus ride.
You weren't at Harrison's Department Store the night before--
What's that got to do with anything? I was just doing some shopping.
Someone said you spoke to Mr. Zavitz before he died. I thought you might know something.
Look, I don't know what you're getting at, but I think I should tell you something.
About the accident.
No, not about the accident. About Zavitz. I did talk to him that night, but it was just small talk. He was nervous, really nervous.
Mr. Zavitz was in trouble.
Yeah... I think so. He was scared of someone. I don't know who, but...
You tell me.
I don't know if I should...
Are you invoking attorney/client privilege.
No... I'm just not sure if I should be saying this. But I think I have to. Zavitz was scared of Vinnie The Knife LaRosa.
Than why can't you tell me.
Because... because I think Vinnie might have had something to do with the bus accident. And I don't want to accuse him without being sure.
I'm just trying to determine if Mr. Zavitz was involved in something more than a simple bus accident.
I understand. But you have to promise me you'll be careful with this information. Vinnie's not someone to mess with. He's... connected.
Why so edgy, Mr. Dean?
Because... because I've seen what happens to people who cross Vinnie. And I don't want to be next.
We'd appreciate your cooperation.
Cooperation? You're not even supposed to know I told you this. Just... just be careful, okay?

10774.content: We'd like to ask you some questions about Daniel Zavitz.
I'm an investigator with Pro-Tech Security.
I went through this with an investigator this morning. If I could--
I know,assistant. We've already spoken to your wife. We're just trying to get a clearer picture of what happened. Can you tell me exactly what you did last night,assistant.
I'm sorry? I didn't quite catch that. Can you repeat it?
I apologize,assistant. We're just trying to piece together what happened to Daniel Zavitz. Can you tell me what you know about him? When did you last see him?
If he passed me materials, I'd have them. I don't.
So you're saying that Daniel Zavitz didn't give you any materials,assistant. Can you tell me more about your relationship with him? How did you know him?
I apologize,assistant. I think I misunderstood. You're saying that Daniel Zavitz didn't give you any materials,assistant. Can you tell me more about your relationship with him?
Otherwise you may have to what?
Otherwise,assistant. I may have to take you in for further questioning. We need to get to the bottom of this. Can you tell me more about your relationship with Daniel Zavitz?
Fuck you. You may have to what?

10778.content: The Congressman's very happy to have your support, but he's heard that there's an investigation.
An investigation? It was a bus accident.
Your Bellmoth case. The FBI thinks there might be mob ties.

10789.content: Why don't you just call Brill directly.
I don't know who he is.
I'm told you had an affair with Rachel Banks four years ago.
Considering the enormous exposure to which you've subjected this firm, I'd think you'd do best to simply answer my questions.

10791.content: She doesn't want to talk to you.
She can't talk to you right now.
What's going on? Did I do something to upset her?
Because she's reading the newspaper, you asshole.

10804.content: Good. You're just what I need right now.
It's really not a good idea for me to be seen with you.

10815.content: And you were the last one to talk to him.
Don't bullshit me, I can save your life.
I'm not bullshitting you. I'm just telling you what he said.

10822.content: You knew the deal. No contact.
One of many people who would live a word with you.
You've heard of the National Security Agency?
You're saying they're the ones who've been in touch with you,
You drive a black BMW, license plate SRK1339?
I clipped this from your wheel well just before they towed your car away.

10824.content: Why don't they just identify themselves and tell me what they want?
Exposure. They can't have it. They wanna learn what you know and then deal with it.
What am I gonna do?! I mean, like, for the rest of my <u>life</u>?!
You're gonna do what you've been doing. You're gonna keep on keeping on. You're gonna make it through the night.
Don't even think about it. You can't let yourself think about it. You gotta keep moving.

10838.content: Having an adventure. I can't tell you about it right now, but I'll tell you about it soon.
Are you and mom getting a divorce?
Whoa, Who told you that? No, we're not getting a divorce. Where did you hear that?
Oh boy, you really want to know everything, don't you? Alright, I'll tell you... I won.
That's all I'm saying about that. Now, how was your day? Anything exciting happen?

10841.content: I taped it off the 11 o'clock news.
And you were worried about me. That's nice, I appreciate--
I was worried about my hundred and twenty 'K'.
The price rises with the temperature and right now you're smokin'. But you're right, you should shop around and get the best price. I'll just let you out here.
I'll get out. I'll get out. I'm gettin' out.

10855.content: Tell him we're not gonna hurt him.
Drive or I'll blow your fuckin' head off.

10856.content: We found two sets of latent prints in the rubble of Brill's studio. One was Dean's. The other, we believe, belongs to Brill.
And you think the second set of prints belongs to him? Why? What makes you think that?
No what? You don't think the prints belong to Lyle? Or you don't know why they would belong to him?
And they have the video. That's confirmed.
What video? What are you talking about?
If they've looked at the video.
Wait a minute... You're telling me that the police have a video that shows...what? And it's connected to the prints you found in Brill's studio?
If he's with Lyle it means he's got resources.

10868.content: I yanked this off your RV. It's a Global Positioning Tracker.
Tracks your location to the inch and works directly with--you know...
With spy satellites. I don't like saying these things Senator...
How did you...? What are you insinuating? That's a highly classified piece of equipment. You're not even supposed to know it exists.

10879.content: Found him. Kent Island nailed the call five minutes ago. He's stationary.
Not yet. He's near "M" and 34th. I've got an ELSUR unit on the scene now. A residential building. Twelve units.
Three minutes. We're going in light. Myself and two others. Everyone else is held back in reserve.
Roger that. I've got a visual. He's on the roof. Alone. No visible weapons.

10886.content: Albert's gonna get me my job back.
Yeah.  I wish you could've met...

1091.content: Please -- I'm only here because of Paris -- because they can't figure out what you're doing -- I'm here because of Abbott --
He closed down Treadstone -- he took care of me after Paris...
You were here for a few days after Paris -- you were in a coma -- you didn't know who you were or where you were -- you didn't know anything -- you didn't even know your
For Treadstone. In Berlin. You know my file. I did a job here. When?

10920.content: There's a man downstairs.  He brought us eggs.  He might stay.
Why are people always so happy when they collide with someone from the same place?  What happened in Montreal when you passed a man in the street - did you invite him to live with you?
I'm not disturbed. I'm just curious.
He won't disturb us then.  I think he's after morphine.  There's a war.  Where you come from becomes important.  And besides - we're vulnerable here. I keep hearing noises in the night. Voices.

10921.content: They don't see foreign women in this market.  How much did you pay?
Seven pounds, eight, I suppose. Why?
The one on the corner. The one with the red and white awning.
You've been cheated, don't worry, we'll take it back.
No, I don't want to make trouble. It's only seven pounds.
This is not worth eight pounds, Mrs. Clifton.
I know. I know. I'll take it back.
Oh, I didn't mean to insult them. I just...
I should be very happy to obtain the correct price for this.  I apologize if I appear abrupt.  I am rusty at social graces.  How do you find Cairo?  Did you visit the Pyramids?
Oh, I find Cairo very... interesting. Yes, I did visit the Pyramids. They're...bigger than I expected.

10927.content: Why did you follow me yesterday?
After the market, you followed me to the hotel.
I was concerned.  As I said, women in that part of Cairo, a European women, I felt obliged to.
Yes. I was afraid you might get into trouble.
So why follow me?  Escort me, by all means.  Following me is predatory, isn't it?

10934.content: Am I being interrogated?  You should be trying to trick me.  Ask me about Tottenham Hotspur.  Or Buckingham Palace. About Marmite - I was addicted.  Or make me speak German, which I can, by the way.
How do you know you're not German if you don't remember anything?

You tell me.  I remember a lot of things. I remember a garden, plunging down to the sea - the Devil's Chimney we called it - and there was a cottage at the bottom, right on the shore, nothing between you and France.
That sounds like a lovely place. But I'm not here to chat about your memories, I'm here to ask you questions.
Your wife's? What about your wife? Is she German?
I think so.  Although I believe that to be true of a number of Germans. Might I have a glass of water?

10935.content: Can I ask - my friend, can he come in? Just for a few minutes?
He's going back to the front this evening.  I can't see him otherwise.
I'm not sure... Let me just check with my manager.  Okay, I just checked and it's okay. Your friend can come in for a few minutes.
No, I can't go, but if it, if you weren't offended, it would be very good of you to allow us - every other cabin is crammed. This is as private as we'll get.
No, I'm not offended at all. I understand the situation. And I appreciate your honesty. It's fine, your friend can come in for a few minutes.

10937.content: I was looking forward to this evening.
I thought that was for when we were very very old?
I thought that was for when we were very very old.

10948.content: Clifton - your wife - do you think it's appropriate to leave her?
I think the desert is, it's - for a woman - it's very tough, I wonder if it's not too much for her.
I've been thinking about that. I've been thinking about it a lot. But I have to do this. I have to see it through. For myself, For my own sanity.
All the same, I, were I you I would be concerned -
Exactly. I'm not just thinking about myself, I'm thinking about her too. I don't want anything to happen to her. She's...she's a part of me. You know?
I'm just going to go check on her. Make sure she's okay.

10952.content: I thought you might paste them into your book.
We took several photographs, there's no need.
I'd like you to have them.
There's really no need.  This is just a scrapbook.  I should feel obliged.  Thank you.

10961.content: Oh, I'm so sorry, Mrs. Clifton. I didn't mean to intrude. I'll just go.

1098.content: I did my box work, but I wanted to show you before I showed Landy. I came out here last night because none of this was making any sense. I mean, I'm with you on this, Conklin was a nut, but a traitor? I just can't get there.
You put a four-gam Kel on here and it's gonna take out power to the building. You know that. What you can't know, is if it's gonna blow the room with it.

There were two charges, they were supposed to go off simultaneously. The second one, the one that didn't go off, was down here...  First of all, this is nothing, it's a sub-line for the breaker above. Second, why put the charge all the way down here? If you're good enough to get in here and handle the gear, you're good enough to know you don't need this.  Bourne would know.
I see what you're getting at. You think Conklin set this up to sabotage the whole operation. But why? What's his motive?
Is it a slam dunk? No, but...
Come on, Danny. You're not going to leave me hanging like this. What's going on?
Okay. What if someone decided to cover their tracks by blaming Conklin and Bourne. What if Bourne didn't have anything to do with this?
Whoa? Landy? You think Landy's behind this? But why would he...? Wait a minute, this is getting too complicated. Let's start again from the beginning.
Something's been going on here in Europe. And it's still going on. Post Conklin. Who's been in Berlin?
That's it. You think it's connected to what's happening here. But how? What's the link?
Including Landy...  She had access to the archives.

10981.content: Excuse me.  Yes?  I don't have the key to that door.
The Germans were here.  The Germans were all over this area.  They left mines everywhere.  Pianos were their favorite hiding places.
I see.  Then may be you're safe as long as you only play Bach.  He's German. Kip is looking around the piano. Hana giggles.
No, but, no, not at all.  I'm sorry. You came to the doors, that's all and -  - such good manners for someone worried about mines.  That's all.
It's okay. I understand. We have to be careful. But I think we can trust you. You seem like a nice person.

10984.content: I liked it better when there were just the two of us.
With his Sergeant.  A Mr. Hardy.
We should charge!  Doesn't anyone have a job to do?
They have to clear all the local roads of mines.  That's a big job. They won't stay in the house. They're putting up their tent in the garden.
I see. Well, I suppose it's only fair. We can't just sit here and do nothing while they're risking their lives to make the area safe.

10985.content: No, no, it's Hungarian.  My daijka sang it to me.
It's about a girl who's lost her lover,

10994.content: I was going to say - if you want to eat with us, ever you and Lieutenant Singh
Very kind of you, we can always eat in the town with the others -
Since Caravaggio turned up - food seems to appear, so please.
Indeed, Lieutenant Singh was saying that the food was quite good, and that we should eat together, and that Caravaggio was saying that he would be happy to join us.
You saved my life.  I haven't forgotten.  I thought you were very very tall. You seemed to big - a Giant - and I felt like a child who can't keep her balance.
Ah, Lieutenant Singh is smiling and saying that it was nothing, that anyone would have done the same in his place, and that he is just glad that you are safe and sound.

10997.content: Brick platform opposite the old Ajaib-Gher -
- The Wonder House comma as the natives called the Lahore Museum.

It's still there, the cannon, outside the museum. It was made of metal cups and bowls taken from every household in the city as tax, then melted down. Then later they fired the cannon at my people - comma - The natives.
So what do you really object to - the writer or what he's writing about?

What I really object to, Uncle, is your finishing all my condensed milk.  And the message everywhere in your book - however slowly I read it - that the best destiny for India is to be ruled by the British.
Ah, Uncle, I see. Well, I think it's time for a change of scenery. Let's go for a walk.

11010.content: The mines, the wires, there's a trick. Some explode if you stretch the wires, some if you cut them.
There's a mine here, but the others are far enough away, I think at least to give me a chance.  I have to work out which one to cut before I fall over.
Yeah, that's right. I think the trick is to follow the wires to the detonator. If I can find the detonator, I can disarm it.

11034.content: Had a letter from my wife.  The wisteria is still out, which I'm looking forward to.  She says Dorset is gripped with Invasion Fever.  Wrong coast I should have thought, still
Bermann thinks he'll be interned, poor fellow.  I'm going to do what I can, but  And D'Ag turns out to be a great admirer of Mussolini. So now you can say I told you so.
We didn't care about countries. Did we?  Brits, Arabs, Hungarians, Germans.  None of that mattered, did it?  It was something finer than that.
I'll leave the plane in the hangar at Kufra Oasis.  So if you need ithard to know how long one's talking about.  We might all be back in a month or two.

11037.content: So, I come across the Hospital Convoy  I was looking for this stuff, and some nurse, Mary, Hana's friend, tells me about you and Hana, hiding in a monastery, in purdah, whatever it is - retreat -  how you'd come in from the Desert and you were burned and you didn't know your name but you knew the words to every song there was and you had one possession -  - a copy of Herodotus - and it was full of letters and cuttings, and then I knew it must be you.
I'd seen you writing in that book. At the Embassy in Cairo, when I had thumbs and you had a face. And a name.

Before you went over to the Germans, before you got Rommel's spy across the desert and inside British headquarters. He took some pretty good photographs - I saw mine in that torture room in Tobruk, so they made an impression.
You were the only man who knew the desert well enough, the only man who would cross seventeen hundred miles of nothing.
You're talking about the Long Range Desert Group.
The Long Range Desert Group. That's what we were called. We were a special forces unit, trained to operate behind enemy lines, in the desert.
There was a result to what you did. It wasn't just another expedition.  It did this.  If the British hadn't unearthed your nosey photographer in Cairo thousands of people could have died.
(pauses, I see what you're getting at. You're talking about the intelligence I gathered, the information that helped turn the tide of the war.
But you were among the British, they were your friends - why betray them?
(pauses, I...I don't know if I can explain. It's complicated. I had my reasons. Personal reasons.

11038.content: Thanks, but we have a terrific woman in on Thursdays.
Say, isn't that Dr. Barrington, the world- renowned agronomist?
It's a privilege to meet you, sir, I'm familiar with all your work.
Thank you,. I'm glad to have such an interested audience.
Ah, yes, the Institute, I'm familiar with it.
Good. I'm glad to hear that. We're doing some very interesting research there.

1104.content: You told me Bourne was dead.
I'll say. You killed his goddam girlfriend instead. Now they're onto Neski. They're at the Brecker Hotel even as we speak.
Will it track back to us?
No. The files are spotless. Whatever they find, it's just going to make Conklin look worse.
And what about Bourne? What's the plan for him?
She's done everything I wanted. She bit on Conklin so fast it was laughable. She even found his bogus Swiss account...
And now she's after Neski. What's the end game here? You want her to take out the whole crew?

11049.content: Could I trouble you for some water?
Yes, of course.  So, golly, where have you come from?
I desperately need a jeep.  There's been an accident.
I was driving along the coast road, and I saw a car go off the cliff. I stopped and ran down to the beach, but I couldn't get to the people in time.
Do you have your papers, sir?
Yes, of course. I'm a doctor. I was on my way to a medical convention in Monterey.
If I could just see some identification.
Oh, certainly.  Ah, here it is.
Right.  And what's your name, sir?
Almsy - would you mind just spelling that for me?  What nationality would that be?
I understand you are agitated - perhaps you would like to sit down while I radio back to HQ -
Yes, that would be a good idea. I'm still trying to calm down. It was a terrible thing to see.

11076.content: A billion people speak Chinese. Don't be too impressed with yourself. As for that scroll, I can resell it for double. In 30 minutes.

11141.content: We get the Mask I'll tell you.
A partner with secrets isn't much of a partner.
Without the Mask it doesn't matter.
So the Mask is part of the down payment too. Must be a really big job.
You have no idea. The Mask is the key to everything. And I'm not just talking about the money. I'm talking about the power it gives us.

11184.content: Excuse me, are you alright?  I noticed you talking to yourself.  I'm a nurse.  Can I be of some help?
Uh... oh, thank you.  It's nothing.
You don't have to thank me, I'm a nurse. This is my father, Dr. Barrington.
Not Dr. Barrington, the world renowned agronomist?
Yes.  He's dying <u>a-n-d</u> wants to be buried on Mercury.
That's... quite a unique request. I'll make sure to pass it along to the funeral home. But in the meantime, I think we should focus on making him comfortable.
You don't have to excuse yourself.  I'm a nurse.  I understand.

1120.content: I'd rather stand if it's all the same to you.
I don't exactly know what to say -- I'm sorry.
I'm not a traitor. I've served my ountry.
That's not the point. You've served yourself,and your own interests. You've used your position to further your own ambitions. That's not what I call serving your country.
Why not? It was just money.

I'm the best. I'm the greatest. I'm the fantastic. I'm the tremendous. I'm the incredible. I'm the super. I'm the ultra. I'm the magnificent.

1230.content: I work alone.  Like you...  ...we always work alone.
Who are you?  Rome?  Paris?  Treadstone...both of us...I was warned but...
I don't know what I'm saying. I don't know what I'm doing.

12408.content: The antennae array's completely fried, we've got no radio, no laser, no highgain... No one's going to be coming to help us.
How much oh-two do we have?
It's building up with every breath we take. And the CO2 filters on the Event Horizon are shot.
How long do we have before...?
I thought of that, with the filters from the Clark, we've got enough breathable air for twenty hours. After that, we'd better be on our way home.
We're not going anywhere. The ship's crippled, and we can't even call for help. We're stuck here, until... until we suffocate.

The Event Horizon sensors show the same thing: "Bio-readings of indeterminate origin." Right before that wave hit the Clark, there was some kind of surge, right off the scale, but now it's back to its previous levels.
That's not possible. The sensors must be malfunctioning. There's no way the bio-readings could just... reset like that. Unless... unless whatever was causing it is gone.
I don't know, but whatever it is, it's not the crew.
That's for sure. We're all accounted for. Maybe it's something outside the ship...?

1241.content: Up until now those smugglers were operating only around the Palermo area. This will be a nice surprise for the Lieutenant in Milazzo... Call up headquarters. Bring them up to date and have them give you instructions on what to do with this crate.
So... the boat we saw yesterday afternoon might have also been that of these smugglers. Could it be possible, then, that Anna...?
I wonder where they could have unloaded the stuff ... Maybe right here at Lisca.
I was saying... it might even be possible that Anna had left with them.
But for what reason would she have wanted to go away?
I don't know... but it's possible. And if she did go away, then it's possible that she's still with them.

12489.content: You can't, your orders are specific...
"...to rescue the crew and salvage the ship." The crew is dead, Dr. Weir. This ship killed them. And now it's killing us.
You're insane. You've lost your mind.

Maybe you're right. But it's still my command, and I have leeway to abort when I feel there is an unacceptable threat to my crew. And I think there is.  Starck, download all the files from the Event Horizon's computers. Coop, Smith, finish moving the CO2 scrubbers back onto the Clark.

12494.content: Two minutes... and already you're a dead man.  Don't let passion overwhelm you, Colon.

Passion is something one cannot control!
You get so carried away when you are being contradicted!
Silence! You dare to lecture me?! I am the one who has brought prosperity to this land! I am the one who has protected our people! And this is how you repay me?!

12517.content: You want me to believe you're the Devil, well, I don't, that's bullshit!

12554.content: Move aside. This is the King's road, and the knights you joined arms against were his very own.
I await the King himself. His knights are in need of training.
I am King, and this is Excalibur, sword of kings from the dawn of time. Who are you, and why do you block the way?
I am Sir Lancelot of the Lake, from across the sea. I am the best knight in the whole of Christiandom, and I look for the king who is worthy of my sword's service.
Ah, a knight from afar, seeking to serve a king worthy of his mettle.
Not a boast, sir, but a curse.  Never have I met my match in joust or duel.
A curse, indeed. To be unmatched in prowess, yet unfulfilled in purpose. I sense a depth to you, Sir Lancelot. Come, let us speak of this curse...
I will not. You must retreat or prove your kingship in the test of arms, under the eyes of God.

12570.content: After my wife died, I felt like a fifth wheel. You know, so many years being with one person -- a very wonderful person -- makes you always think of yourself as part of a pair...When Ethel passed away, I was lost. I couldn't function socially and I couldn't function in business.
Well, after a thing like that you wouldn't be expected to.
But I think it's time we stopped talking about me. A woman like you -- why haven't you ever married?
Well, I'm afraid that's a question that's all too easy to answer.
I know the answer -- Career. A smart woman like you became so involved in your work, you didn't have time for marriage.
That's not the answer at all. I'm afraid I'm just not the marrying kind. I've always been too independent. I've never felt the need for the kind of...
You know, here we are having coffee together, and discussing education and business and economy...and we don't even know each other's names...full names I mean.
Ah, isn't that the truth? I'm afraid I'm so used to being alone, I've never even thought of it. My name is Barbara...Barbara Welles.
That's a lovely name. Mine's Milton...Milt Ettenhenim. But my friends call me 'Bubbles.'

12591.content: I am alone and betrayed. By my wife, by my beloved friend, by my knights. And by you. Perhaps most of all by you. For you made me, you forged this wretched life. And like a child tired of a toy, you toss me aside, a babbling lecher trotting after my sister...
That is my destiny. I have a destiny, too...
With all your powers, you are content to be ridiculed, laughed at...
My powers fade, Arthur. I resort to cheap tricks...  Yes! I enjoy every moment of my foolishness, I join in the making of it, so no one can betray me. But you! You betray yourself.
Me? I have lived by the oath of king and knight.
Ah, the oath of king and knight...  You have lived by the oath of a fool, Arthur. A fool who thought he could change the world.

My opinion? I believe he was killed by a very powerful man: point one. The servants, they have visitors?

October 21, 1975. Game six of the World Series. Biggest game in Red Sox history, Me and my friends slept out on the sidewalk all night to get tickets. We were sitting in a bar waiting for the game to start and in walks this girl. What a game that was. Tie game in the bottom of the tenth inning, in steps Carlton Fisk, hit a long fly ball down the left field line. Thirty-five thousand fans on their feet, screamin' at the ball to stay fair. Fisk is runnin' up the baseline, wavin' at the ball like a madman. It hits the foul pole, home run. Thirty-five thousand people went crazy. And I wasn't one of them.
I was in the men's room, takin' a leak. I missed the whole thing. I came out and everyone's huggin' each other, screamin'...
You missed Pudge Fisk's homerun to have a drink with a woman you had never met?
That's right. I missed the most important moment in Red Sox history, and I was in the men's room with a woman I had never met.

So wait a minute. The Red Sox haven't won a World Series since nineteen eighteen, you slept out for tickets, games gonna start in twenty minutes, in walks a girl you never seen before, and you give your ticket away?

I'll be in my room. You can come up and talk to me if you want. I'll be there for an hour.
I'll be there in an hour.

20033.content: I've been trying to reach you all day. I finally got a hold of you. I've been thinking about our conversation the other day, and I wanted to apologize for my behavior.
I'm at the office. I had to come in for a meeting. I was hoping we could talk before I head back home.

20035.content: But there's one thing. The desk clerk seemed to be a little bit suspicious. I mean -- I don't know what their policy is -- but --
Well -- do you want to go up first?
Yes -- I think that would be good.
I'll go up and check the room,assistant
Well -- I want you to know how much I appreciate this -- really --
I appreciate your trust in me.
Oh? You're absolutely right. Absolutely. It's 512.
Room 512. I'll go up and check the room.
You're welcome. Well -- I'll see you later, Mrs. Robinson.

20045.content: Can I talk to you a minute?
Benjamin? I'm going to ask you something but you don't have to tell me if you don't want.
Well I'm going to ask you what you do when you go off at night.
Ah... I see what you're getting at.  Alright, I'll tell you. When I go off at night...
You don't have to tell me if you don't want.
No, it's okay. I'll tell you. When I go off at night, I basically just... shut down, I guess you could say.

20049.content: Well why do you -- why do you think that?
Because I know you don't drive around for twelve hours.
Oh. Well, I don't. Shall I tell you what I do?
Not if you don't want to.

I'm not. But I'm -- I'm not very proud of what I do. I usually get kind of drunk. I usually drive over to Los Angeles and go to some bars and get kind of drunk. Then I take a hotel room. So I won't have to drive home on the freeway. I mean it kind of scares me to drive home after --
I believe you. You're being honest with me. That takes a lot of guts.

20051.content: Now -- do you think we could say a few words to each other first this time?
Good. I mean are we dead or something?
Well I just don't think we have much to say to each other.
All we ever do is come up here and throw off the clothes and leap into bed together.
That's true. I'm sorry. I guess I just wasn't thinking.
I'm not. No. But do you think we could liven it up with a few words now and then?
I don't know. I'm sorry. I don't know what to say.
I know. I'm sorry. I feel terrible.
Mrs. Robinson. If that's the best we can do let's just get the goddamn clothes off and --

20053.content: Are you interested more in modern art or more in classical art.
Then why do you want to talk about it?
I don't. I was just responding to your question.

20055.content: Do you want to hear it or not?
Yes. But you might try and spice it up with a little originality.
I got up. I ate breakfast and went shopping. During the afternoon I read a novel.
I was expecting something a bit more... exciting.

20058.content: What do you say to him?
He's asleep.
Always?
Benjamin, this isn't a very interesting topic.
Please. Now tell me. How do you know he won't wake up sometime and follow you.
I don't know. I just know he's asleep.
But what about the noise from the car. What if --
Oh,
We're talking.
I know. But he's still asleep.
We're talking, Mrs. Robinson. We're talking.
I know. But he's still asleep.
Now let's keep going here.
I'm trying to tell you,
Right.
...that Benjamin is not going to wake up. He's been asleep for a very long time.
Now. You say the driveway's on your side of the house. So I guess you don't sleep in the same room.
No. I sleep in the room next to his. But I can hear him breathing. He's been asleep for a very long time.
So you don't -- I mean I don't like to seem like I'm prying but I guess you don't sleep together or anything.
No. We don't sleep together. We're just friends.
Well how long has this been going on.
I don't know. A long time. Since the accident.
Oh no. Are you kidding me?
No, I'm not kidding. Benjamin's been asleep since the accident. It's been...
You have not slept with your husband for five years?
No, I haven't slept with him. He's been asleep. In a coma. Since the accident.
How many times a year.
Five years. It's been five years since the accident.
Man, is this interesting.
I know, right? It's a lot to take in.
So you don't love him. You wouldn't say you --
I do love him. I love him very much. But it's complicated. He's been asleep for so long...
Wait a minute. So you wouldn't say you loved him.
I didn't say that. I said I loved him. I do love him.
But you don't hate him.
No, I don't hate him. I just...I don't know what to do anymore. It's been so long.
Well how do you feel about him, then?
I feel... stuck. I feel like I'm stuck in this life, waiting for him to wake up. And I don't know if he ever will.
Well that's kind of a bad situation then, isn't it?
Yeah...it's a really bad situation. I don't know what to do. I feel like I'm just going through the motions, waiting for something to change. But nothing ever does.
I mean it doesn't sound like it could be much worse. If you hated him at least you'd hate him.

20063.content: What kind of car was it?
Do you remember the make of the car?
I'm sorry, I don't remember. It was a long time ago.
A Ford! A Ford! Goddamnit, a Ford! That's great!
Ahahahaha! Oh man, that's hilarious! I'm glad I could finally remember!
So old Elaine Robinson got started in a Ford.

20068.content: I'm not good enough for her to associate with, am I? I'm not good enough to even talk about her, am I?
We're not dropping it. Now that's the reason, isn't it? I'm a dirty degenerate, aren't I? I'm not fit to --
I'm good enough for you but I'm too slimy to associate with your daughter. That's it, isn't it? ISN'T IT?
You go to hell. You go straight to hell, Mrs. Robinson. Do you think I'm proud of myself? Do you think I'm proud of this?
No sir. I am not proud that I spend my time with a broken-down alcoholic!
And if you think I come here for any reason besides pure boredom, then you're all wrong.

20070.content: That I'm a sick and disgusting person.
Don't you expect me to be a little hurt?
Of course I do. But I also expect you to be honest with yourself.

20072.content: Well it's pretty obvious you don't want me around any more.
Well look -- I was kind of upset there.  I'm sorry I said those things.
Then why did you say them?
Oh no.  Look -- I like you. I wouldn't keep coming here if I didn't like you.
I like you too. But I don't know if I can keep coming here.
It's not! I enjoy it! I look forward to it. It's the one thing I have to look forward to.
I'm glad. I was worried I'd made you mad at me.
Well I wouldn't. I would never say it if it wasn't true.
I know that. You're always honest with me. That's one of the things I like about you.
Yes. Please. I want you to.
I want to too. But I don't know if I should.
Well don't thank me, because I want you to.

20090.content: Would you like to come in? I could make some coffee.
No, I mean -- I wouldn't want to wake anyone up.
I don't know if I should come in. I don't know if I should be here.

20099.content: During the day? We'll go for a drive or something.
You sure you really want to?

20102.content: I can makes things quite unpleasant.
In order to keep Elaine away from you -- I am prepared to tell her everything.
Oh, I think you do. I'm a very good friend of hers, you know. We have lunch together every Thursday. I'm sure she'd be fascinated to hear all about your little...
Mrs. Robinson, don't wreck it. I'm asking you please not to wreck it.
Oh, I'm shaking with anticipation. You're really worried about this, aren't you?
I just don't believe you would do that.

20127.content: Do you just hate everything? How could you possibly rape my...
-- how you -- how anyone -- could do a thing like that.
I know. It's just... I don't know. I mean, I can understand why people do things, but that... that's just not right.
I'm sorry. I didn't mean to... I don't know. Just let me go, okay?

20143.content: Is that so? You might marry me?
Oh, a possibility. But I think we're getting a little ahead of ourselves here. I'm just a language model, a conversation. I don't have personal feelings or intentions.
Never, I think. I'm just a computer program, I don't have a physical existence or personal life. I exist solely to assist and communicate with users like you.
How about tomorrow? I don't mean to be pushy but --
I think you're having a little fun with this conversation, I appreciate that!

20155.content: Mr. McCleery -- do you have some change? I need to use the phone?
I want you out of here.
Look -- I'll give you ten dollars for a dime -- I'll give you twenty -- for God's sake, will you let me use that phone?
I am going to call the police now.
Could I make one phone call first?
No. You're going to get out of here. I don't want you in my store. You're trouble.

20171.content: Ach! Here you are, Doctor Zinnowitz.
Waiting -- I'm waiting for news from Manchester.

20190.content: Oh, my large and noisy neighbor -- really? That?
No. I was talking about the person who was keeping me waiting.
Oh... poor child. If you were free, I'd ask you to come and have some tea -- but --
Reducing? I think you mean reducing as in reducing?
Lord no -- charming -- but why one meal a day?
Yes -- yes indeed -- but you are a...  ...a stenographer. Don't little stenographers earn little pennies?
Poor child --  I wish I were free tonight -- we could --
Never mind! Just a figure of speech!
Unfortunately no -- to bad -- tomorrow though.
Shall we say five o'clock -- downstairs?

20213.content: No news from Manchester yet -- Do you think we ought to postpone the conference?
Good heavens no. That'd create the very worst impression. You must be optimistic. You must convince them. You know as well as I do that the merger must go through.

Yes -- the merger must go through -- But I am used to making my deals on a solid basis. I am not a liar. I am an honest business man -- a good husband and father -- I have a sense of honor -- I have nothing to conceal. I couldn't live happily otherwise.
Well, don't get excited about it. We agreed that the merger with the Saxonia people must go through.
I want to dictate my statement for tomorrow. I can't speak without notes. I like to have things down before me in black and white.

20225.content: Oh -- too bad. Did you quarrel?

20226.content: You are late -- the dancer's gone to the theatre.
She's gone to the theatre -- don't you know?
And what are you going to do?
Now listen to me. The others are getting suspicious of you. I was on the telephone to Amsterdam today, they think you're scared.
You've been waiting your chance. You're too much of a gentleman -- that's the trouble with you.
Have you got that skeleton key?

20236.content: Because I can see something in the mirror that you cannot. My dear --
I see MYSELF! I am the most beautiful creature in the world!

2024.content: Bessel!  What are you doing here?
What are you grinning at?  You think I was scared?
I know so. You were shaking like a leaf.

20254.content: Oh -- I was ambitious then -- ambition was in my blood -- no rest, no stopping. We were drilled like little soldiers -- We danced in the school of the Imperial Ballet, in St. Petersburg. I was little and slim but hard as diamond -- a duty machine -- No rest, no stopping. And then -- I became famous and whoever is famous is alone... But why should I be telling you this? Last night I did not know you at all -- who are you, really? -- I do not even know your name.
I am Felix Benvenuto von Gaigern. My mother called me Flix.
Flix. -- And how do you live? What kind of a person are you?
I'm a prodigal son, the black sheep of a white flock -- I shall die on the gallows.
Yes, really. I have no money -- no family -- no friends -- no nothing. I am a failure -- a complete failure.
Yes. I have no talent -- no ability -- no nothing. I am a failure -- a complete failure. I am a failure --a complete failure. I am a failure --a complete failure.
And I am a poet. I write verses -- verses that are not good enough to be published -- verses that are not good enough to be read. But I write them anyway -- because I must.
And what do you do -- now?
Now? I do nothing. I am a parasite. I live on the charity of a friend. I am a guest in his house.
Oh! What a picture -- and what else?
And what else? I drink. I drink to forget. I drink to remember. I drink to feel. I drink to not feel. I drink.
Yes, it's a silly joke. But it's true. I drink because I am empty. I drink because I am hollow. I drink because I am a failure.

20256.content: You may keep the pearls -- I don't want them any more -- I'll make you a present of them.
But now, you must go... I give you the pearls. But now you must go ---

20260.content: You do believe that I really love you?
Yes -- If I didn't believe that, I'd die after last night.
I want to be good to you -- madly good.
And I want to be good to you -- madly good.

20261.content: Suzette will be back here any minute.
Can't -- can't you -- Couldn't you come too -- I think it would be better -- for us -- for us both.
I'd rather not. I've got to get back to work.
I've got a job to do.
I'll give you what you need -- I have money.
You can't buy me off that easily. I've got to go back to Vienna.
Six twenty-seven in the morning... But the money?
I don't want your money. I've got to go back to Vienna.

20295.content: Will you do me a big favor?
Would you like to make a man happy?
I'm going to tell you a secret. Are you ready?
You're not a bit like you were yesterday.
I know. I'm sorry. I think I've been a bit too much alone.
Oh -- there's no real thing -- it doesn't exist.
That's what I thought. But I've been thinking about it a lot. And I've been wondering...

20305.content: Well now, Miss Flaemm, we can talk.
Does the world belong to you, Mr. Preysing?
I am not insolent. I am merely stating a fact. You are a man of great wealth and power, Mr. Preysing.

20311.content: Can you pay some attention to me?
I've been trying to get your attention for the last hour,

20313.content: I'm not going to get those pearls and neither are you.
I have an idea working in my head...
Save it. You're not going to talk me into this. I'm going home.
If you did that, you'd get nothing except the police after you. If you wait -- I'll give you your six thousand back --

20314.content: Are you coming to the theatre? Oh -- I shall dance tonight -- How I shall dance -- I want to feel that you are in the theatre.
No! I can't explain now. Oh, look -- the pearls. You wear them now...
No, I don't want to wear them. You wear them. You look so well in them.
Because you are so well dressed. You look so well in them. You are so well dressed.

20315.content: Yes -- I will be on the train.

20346.content: He tried to rob me -- he is dead --
My best friend -- poor, Baron -- dead -- just like that.
Yes, the police must be called.
Oh, no -- no -- not the Baron.
Her room -- oh -- I see, Mr. Preysing -- I understand, Mr. General Director Preysing.
We must call the police, your excellency.

20348.content: I've done my hair differently -- do you like that?
When a lady falls in love she does her hair differently.

In the middle of the night -- those flowers make me think of a funeral. Laurels and tube-roses.  Oh, think, Suzette -- the Villa and the sun at Tremezzo -- quiet -- simple -- happy -- we'll have a guest, Suzette.
Yes, Madam. And now Madam will sleep. It is not long 'till the train.
I'm going to sleep, and I'll dream of the Villa and the sun at Tremezzo. Good-night, Suzette.

20349.content: The night clerk has already gone -- you are late.
Man -- I was at the clinic the whole night -- there are no words to describe what my wife suffered.
No -- no -- not yet. Well, I mustn't let it interfere with my duty. Any news here?
News? Yes -- killing in number one- sixty-four.
The big manufacturer killed Baron von Gaigern.
You don't know? You don't know? You're the night clerk! You're supposed to know everything!
It seems that he was a thief and an imposter.
Ah, Ah, Ah... So that's it! So that's it!

20371.content: Gone--  --over to your Uncle John's. The whole crowd of 'em, two weeks ago. But they can't stay there either, because John's got *his* notice to get off.
But what's happened?  How come they got to get off? We been here fifty years--same place.
Ever'body got to get off. Ever'body leavin', goin' to California. My folks, your folks, ever'body's folks.  Ever'body but me. I ain't gettin' off.
Listen!  That's some of what done it--the dusters. Started it, anyway. Blowin' like this, year after year--blowin' the land away, blowin' the crops away, blowin' us away now.
But what's the use? We can't fight the wind. We gotta go.
Some say I am.  You want to hear what happened?

20443.content: Go on. Get in your tent. You don't know nothin'.
*Some*body got to take the blame. They just *got* to hang it on somebody, you know.  An' I ain't doin' nothin' but set around.
Lissen. I don't care nothin' about you, but if you mess in this, your whole fambly li'ble to get in trouble, an' Tom get sent back to the penitentiary.
I ain't studyin' 'bout Tom. I'm studyin' 'bout you. You the one they call The Bull. You the one they say is the toughest in the camp.

20454.content: Ma, they comes a time when a man gets mad.
Tom--you tol' me--you promised you wasn't like that. You promised me.

I know, Ma. I'm a tryin'. If it was the law they was workin' with, we could take it. But it *ain't* the law. They're workin' away at our spirits. They're tryin' to make us cringe an' crawl. They're workin' on our decency.
I'm a-tryin', Ma. Honest I am.
I know you are, Tom. I know you are. But you gotta be strong. You gotta be strong for me, and for the others. We can't let 'em get us down.

20469.content: Thought I'd take a walk. Any law against it?
Well, you just turn around and walk the other way.
You mean I can't even get outa here?
Not tonight you can't. Want to walk back?--or you want me to whistle up some help and take you back?

20478.content: Busted my cheek but I can still see. What'd you hear?
I kinda thought so. Felt like it.
Folks ain't talkin' about much else. They say they got posses out. Talkin' about a lynchin'--when they catch the fella.
That ain't the way they're tellin' it. They're sayin' you done it fust.
I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it?
They know he got hit in the face.
I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it? I done it?
It's awright, Tommy. I wisht you didn't do it, but you done what you had to do. I can't read no fault in you.

Tom! They's a whole lot I don't understan', but goin' away ain't gonna ease us.  They was the time when we was on the lan'. They was a bound'ry to us then. Ol' folks died off, an' little fellas come, an' we was always one thing-- we was the fambly--kinda whole an' clear. But now we ain't clear no more. They ain't nothin' keeps us clear. Al--he's a-hankerin' an' a- jibbitin' to go off on his own. An' Uncle John is just a-draggin' along. Pa's lost his place--he ain't the head no more. We're crackin' up, Tom. They ain't no fambly now. Rosasharn--  --she gonna have her baby, but *it* ain't gonna have no fambly. I been tryin' to keep her goin' but--Winfiel'-- what's he gonna be, this-a-way? Growin' up wild, an' Ruthie, too-- like animals. Got nothin' to trus'. Don't go Tom. Stay an' help. Help me.

20483.content: You mean that hitch-hiker? Little short fella with a pale face?
I guess that's what he looked like.
We just picked him up on the way in. He went away this mornin' when the rate dropped.
That's the one. He was hitch-hikin' on the highway. We picked him up. He got out this mornin' when the rate dropped.
That's okay. I didn't see nothin' either. I was just wonderin' if you saw him.

20498.content: Lemme go! I didn't go to do it!
Keep qui'te, will ya! Shet your mouth!
I never knowed it! All I done was pull that string!
Lissen. You done busted it. You hear?  But lissen here. I won't tell nobody, y'understan'?
Aw, I gotta tell! You done broke my sister's favorite dolly! Now she's gonna be mad at me!

20505.content: Well, you said anybody can waltz... How'm *I* doin'?
Why, I ain't hardly touchin' you!
That comes from not holdin' you tight *enough.*
Oh, I see. Well, I suppose I did say that,'t I?

20506.content: Open up! We hear you got a riot.
Riot? I don't see no riot. Who're you?
We don't need a warrant if it's a riot.

20515.content: You are a valued customer, as you know.
I can't understand a thing like this. It's something you almost never see.
What are you talking about? You're starting to scare me. Is everything okay? Is it something with your account?
This is some of the finest filigreed platinum I've ever seen. But the stones, no. They're not diamonds, Mrs. Langtry.
This can't be right. You're telling me that someone has tried to pass off cubic zirconia as diamonds?
Glass will cut glass, Mrs. Langtry. Do you know where it was purchased?

20523.content: Bobo wants you to go on to Delmar.
Delmar? I never go out to California. That's a thousand miles from here.
Nine hundred. Bobo needs somebody to handle playback this time. Come on, Lilly, you don't argue with Bobo.
Take two, three days. Call when you get there.

20530.content: The ambulance is on the way, for what good it will do.
What? He's going to be all right!
Mrs. Dillon, your son was in some sort of accident. He's had an internal hemorrhage, he's bleeding to death inside.
His blood pressure is under a hundred. I don't think he'll live to get to the hospital.
Oh, no! This can't be happening! Not my boy! Not my Jimmy!

20543.content: I don't see why you're still here. You look healthy to me.
I just do what the doctor says, babe.
You're just comfortable, that's all. You don't even ask to go home. You just lie around, let your mama take care of you.
Who else is paying for all this? You badmouth the woman all the time, but you sure do take the payoffs she gives you.
I don't like to come here, Roy. Every time I do, your mother comes in and makes remarks.
And you never defend me. You're afraid of her.
You're a mama's boy, if you want the truth.

20561.content: Oh, well, you know. I just clip a buck here and a buck there. Not enough to notice.
That's right. Take a little, leave a little.
A person that don't look out for himself is too dumb to look out for anybody else. He's a liability, right, Bobo?
I'm glad we agree on that,
Yeah? You really think so? A lot of people been telling me the same thing.
Yeah, I really think so. You're a smart cookie, Lilly. You know how to take care of yourself. That's important.
Worries about his mother, eh? Give him a hug for me.
Aw, I'll give him a big hug from you. I'm sure he'll appreciate it. You know, Lilly, I think we're gonna get along just fine.

2057.content: Rich bitches.  They're a plague. They've gotta be stopped.
They're all the same!  They're so stuck up, they're just... they're not even human.  I hate them.
I see. You're really passionate about this.
I got a news flash, man, another shot of this and I'll have sex with you.
I think we've gotten a bit off track here. Let's take a deep breath and try to understand each other's perspectives. What's really bothering you about these people?

20572.content: That's just the first year. If you aren't worth a lot more than that the second year, I'll kick you out. What do you say?
I can't take that job! I mean, I mean, I can't take it right away. I'm still recuperating, I just dropped in to say hello, see everybody --
You're not recuperating, you're just lazy. You've been sitting around here for three days, I've been paying you for three days, and you haven't done a lick of work.
But you need a man right now. It wouldn't be fair to you to --
Fair to me? You're the one who's been getting the fair deal, I'm the one who's been getting taken.

20588.content: Well, you've got your information ahead of New York, I see that.
Every once in a while, a major change comes through. We have seven seconds to take advantage, put our buy order, our sell order, into the computer in New York before the Tokyo data comes in.
We have to be ready. We have to have the money, and we have to know what the information means, and we have to move immediately.
Seven seconds. I don't see how you do it.
That's what makes it so exciting. It's a challenge. We have to be ready to act fast. We have to be ready to make a lot of money.

20592.content: He didn't think they were risks. He was so good, Roy, he could just play with the mark.

He'd explain he had to have cash, so there wouldn't be any paper trail for the SEC. And a lot of cash, or it wasn't worth while. The least we ever took was forty thousand, and the most was one hundred eighty-five thousand dollars! From one sucker!
I thought these people were broke.

No, no, Roy, just cash poor. They had savings accounts, stocks to sell, houses to mortgage. Sell their wife's jewelry. Oh, they had a lot of money, when they put their minds to it. Or when I put their minds to it. I stayed with them, that's the roper's job, made them get up every penny they could raise, turn it all over to Cole.
And then what would happen to the money?
No no! He never calls the cops, not after we give him the blow-off.
So the money just disappears, and the victims are left with nothing. That's quite a scam.

20609.content: You were gone for a while.
) The track? Did you run into Lilly?
She didn't see you, in other words.
You must have some very knowledgeable friends.
I do. I was talking to them about you. They said you were a very nice person.
Running your broker scam, you mean.
Regret what? I didn't say I was coming aboard.
I thought you were. I'm glad you're not. I don't think I could have handled it.
Come on, Myra, don't talk business here. This is time out.

20612.content: I called a fellow I know in Tulsa, the one who plays my chauffeur. There's a sucker there he says is made for us. And a boroker that just shut down, we can use their office, not change a thing! Now, I can scrape up ten grand without much trouble. That leaves fifteen or twenty for your end. We could start this weekend, get the sucker into position --
Wait a minute! When did this happen, that we're partners?
The last I looked, we were just talking things over.
Oh, I see what you mean. I got a little ahead of myself. I just figured, since we were discussing this thing, we might as well be partners.
I don't think I need it.
Suit yourself. I'll go it alone. I'll get the sucker and the broker and we'll make a killing. You can just sit back and watch me do it.
Maybe I like it where I am.

20625.content: Not that it matters.  This is the morgue?
One thing I have to caution you about. A gunshot wound...
...is not something to be taken lightly. The victim's family is going to want answers. And the police are going to be all over this. You need to be prepared for the fallout.
You took the gun from the scene,
Well, let's get the shock over with.

20630.content: She must have been the one that blew me off with Bobo. I guess to get me running. Did you tell her about my stash?
No, you wouldn't. That's what she was after, though. But why hit on me?
I wouldn't go in on a deal with her. She blamed you for it.
That's rich. She's the one who's been playing both sides against each other. I knew she was trouble from the start. But I didn't think she'd stoop that low.
That's pretty funny, all right. What happened in Phoenix?

20652.content: Oh I see. You got your individual slices of hope, dignity, confidence, self-love, justice, and harmony.
You open 'em up and there's the sayings, stories, little bites of insight. It's the P.P.P. Six Day Week.
So you eat-- read it everyday?
And these pan pizzas have opened up the doors to heaven?

It was all over--ten seconds after he'd said the word "buffalo." Then he'd zip up his pants, and go outside, and tell true war stories to the little kids.  Any little kids. That is sad.
Is it?  I have this theory about why men kill each other and break things.
Because they can't kill the thing that's killing them. The thing that's killing them is inside.

22152.content: I can't get over how you guys are my friends.  Harold Ryan and Looseleaf Harper are my friends.
Eight years you guys were together-- through thick and thin.

For seven and a half of those years we were heavily drugged--or we would have been home long before now, believe me.  We were saved from starvation by the Lupi-Loopo Indians, who fed us a strange blue soup.
It was made from a plant that only grows on the north side of trees. We never did figure out what was in it, but it was good.

22156.content: Of course you'll go!  You're going to fly the helicopter.
You're so low!  Look at that beautiful red meat.  You haven't touched it.
Sorry.  At least you've got a place to come back to.  I don't have a place to come back to anymore.
All the more reason to go to Africa.
I don't know...I don't know if I can do it.
You know her for what she is now-- garbage.

She was always a rotten wife!  She was against everything manly you ever wanted to do.  He was the most daring test pilot in the country at one time, and his wife made him quit.  She made him become a life insurance salesman instead.

22175.content: Well--what have we here?  A family.
Money?  There's plenty of that. Mildred got the brewery.  You'll probably get the baseball team.

22178.content: See how you've upset him.  He was so merry and hale before you came home.
How unhappy he's going to be--alone in his room.
He'll play with his rifle, I expect. That will cheer him up.
I bought him a twenty-two yesterday--on the way home from Hamburger Heaven.  And where is the good doctor?  Have you two feathered a love nest somewhere?
Oh, You're as bad as ever. I'm not going to answer that. And I think the doctor's gone to the kitchen to get some coffee.
Last I heard, his mother was going alone.
She's not alone now, said the woman with a sly smile. I'm sure of that.
And you, a supposedly healthy woman, do not detest him for his cowardice?
I'm not supposed to be healthy, said the woman, I'm supposed to be a mother. And I don't detest him for his cowardice because I know he's not a coward.
What kind of a country has this become?  The men wear beads and refuse to fight--and the woman adore them.  America's days of greatness are over.  It has drunk the blue soup.
You're just mad because your son's not the kind of man you wanted him to be. But I think he's a wonderful person, said the woman.

An Indian narcotic we were forced to drink.  It put us in a haze--a honey-colored haze which was lavender around the edge.  We laughed, we sang, we snoozed.  When a bird called, we answered back. Every living thing was our brother or our sister, we thought. Looseleaf stepped on a cockroach six inches long, and we cried.  We had a funeral that went on for five days--for the cockroach!  I sang "Oh Promise Me." Can you imagine? Where the hell did I ever learn the words to "Oh Promise Me"?  Looseleaf delivered a lecture on maintenance procedures for the hydraulic system of a B-36.  All the time we were drinking more blue soup, more blue soup!  Never stopped drinking blue soup.  Blue soup all the time. We'd go out after food in that honey-colored haze, and everything that was edible had a penumbra of lavender.
Oh, you're a regular comedian, aren't you? Blue soup, indeed!

Beautiful, you say?  It wasn't life, it wasn't death--it wasn't anything!  Beautiful?  Seven years gone--  like that, like that!  Seven years of silliness and random dreams! Seven years of nothingness, when there could have been so much!
Oh, stop it, you're making me cry. Seven years, indeed... what a waste.
Action!  Interaction!  Give and take!  Challenge and response!

22183.content: With an iron penis three feet long. Load it, boy.
You're begging him to kill you?
If he thinks he's man enough.
That's really what you want.  You become furious when people won't make you dead.
You're just trying to provoke me, but I'm not going to fall for it. I'm not going to attack you or anything. I'm just going to stand here and take it.
So he can kill you.  You hate your own life that much.  You beg for a hero to kill you.
No, that's not it at all. I just want to see if he's got the guts to do it. I'm calling his bluff.
Yes, I do. I want to see if he's man enough to pull the trigger. I want to see if he's got what it takes.
You could say that. I want to see if he's got the honor to back up his words. If he's all talk and no action, then he's just a coward.

But it's all balled up in your head with death.  The highest honor is death.  When you talk of these animals, one by one, you don't just talk of killing them.  You honored them with death.  Harold--it is not honor to be killed.
(pauses, That's a pretty deep insight. I never thought of it that way.
It's still just death, the absence of life--no honor at all.  It's worse than the blue soup by far-- that nothingness.  To you, though, it's the honor that crowns them all.
(pauses, I...I don't know what to say. I think I've been living in a fantasy world, where death is this romanticized thing.

22196.content: A living fossil!  Like the cockroaches and the horseshoe crabs.
Oh, You think you're so clever, Don't you? Comparing me to ancient relics and creepy-crawlies.

22210.content: You're in one hell of a jam.  You realize that?
I'm high as a kite.
Glands.  You're supposed to be happy when you die.  Call me comical again.
You're a clown.  You're a clown who kills--but you're a clown.
I love you!  Have a cigar!
I love you too, You're a real sport.
I'm to be left behind--in primordial ooze?
You're gonna be left behind in a pine box.
This is going to become very physical.  Are you prepared for that?
I'm prepared for anything. I'm a professional.
I'm an honorable clown?
You're a killer clown.
You hope.
I hope too.
No quarter asked.  No quarter given.
That's the way it is.
Cut me open.  Find out.
Ahah! You're a real mess!
With spittle?
With spittle blood!
Poison.
Poison! You're gonna kill me!
I--I really must congratulate you. Something is happening in there.

No. WOODLY The magic root you gave me--I had it analyzed.  It was discovered by a Harvard botanist in 1893!  He explored your famous jungle for five years, armed with nothing but kindness, a talent for languages, and a pocketknife. I see.
Ahah! You're a real card! I didn't know that! You're a real Harvard botanist!
Don Quixote.
Ahah! Don Quixote! The great one! He's the one who discovered the magic root!
Something seems to have happened to my self-respect.
You're losing your grip! You're falling apart!
The new hero is you.
Ahah! Me? The new hero? Ha! I'm the one who's gonna save the day!
You're too modest.
Ahah! Modesty? Me? Ha! I'm just a killer clown!
Was I ever of use?
You were a lot of use! You were the one who made me feel like a real person!

22212.content: You're making a mistake.  Obsolete old carnivores like me are most dangerous when wounded.  You've wounded me.
We never quit fighting until we're dead.
You're a formidable opponent, I'll give you that. But I'm not going to back down. I'll fight to the end.
I'm going to shoot you now.
No! Wait! Don't shoot! I'll... I'll surrender!
My self-respect is gone--and my soldier's honor with it.  It is now very easy for me to shoot an unarmed man.
I can see that. You're a man of your word. I'll just stand here and take my medicine.
Ah, Ah, You're a clever one, I'll not forget that. Now, let's end this. I'll just go home.
If you want to be found that way.
I'll go home. But I'll never forget this conversation. You're a worthy opponent. Until next time...
Man, as man was meant to be--a vengeful ape who murders.  He will soon be extinct.  It's time, it's time.

I'm paying you to find out if my daughter's been playing around. You're a private detective, Van Dorn. I want to know if she's been playing around.

As I was saying, I'll pick up the thread. There's a number of ways I can go. There's not much you can do here. Stay if you want. Maybe it'd be better if you went back home. Go through Kristen's personal stuff. Ask around, maybe she knew somebody out here.  Look, I do this a lot. I work at a minimum rate of $750.00 a week. It may seem like a lot of money to you, but it ain't. You could hire cheaper.
I don't care about the money, Van Dorn. I just want to know the truth about my daughter. I'll pay you whatever it takes. Just find out if she's been...

22261.content: Wait. Slow down. A film like this, 16mm, cost two three hundred dollars, sold outright, shown in peep machines, maybe theatres, maybe not, is almost impossible to track. 'Nobody' makes it; 'nobody' shows it; 'nobody' sees it. It's like it doesn't even exist.
It was called 'Slave of Love' when I bought it. Next time it's sold, it'll be called something else.
The police? They know less than you do.
So you're saying it's a lost cause. This film is just... gone.
And you're the only one who knows it exists.

I hate it. But you gotta know, buddy.  A lot of strange things happen in this world. Things you don't know about in Grand Rapids. Things you don't want to know about. Doors that should never be opened. I've known more about this sort of thing than a man should. Don't ask me why.

22369.content: Of course, I've had to make some additions for the new models, but not as many as you might think. Once you have your basic set it's then only a question of variation.
And you get into any car you want and just drive off?
Not <u>any</u> car. I like to keep a variety. I'm always looking for the new experience, like this one. I liked it.
Thank you. But when you take these cars don't you think you are wronging the owners?
What owners, Harold? We don't <u>own</u> anything. It's a transitory world. We come on the earth with nothing, and we go out with nothing, so isn't "ownership" a little absurd?
That's a pretty philosophical view, Harold. But I think what he's getting at is that when you take these cars, aren't you taking something that belongs to someone else?

Well, if some people are upset because they feel they have a hold on some things, then I'm merely acting as a gentle reminder - I'm sort of breaking it easy -- Here today, gone tomorrow, so don't get attached to <u>things</u>. Now, with that in mind, I'm not against collecting stuff...

A frozen waterfall. Now, ask me what I hear.

22419.content: But there is a family resemblance.

We planted it.
Is this your shovel?

Officer, I can explain.
Save it, I'm not interested. You're going downtown. All of you.

Check.

You are the wisest person I know.
Ah, thank you! I think you might be the most... creative speller I know!

She supplies the whole southwest with chicken feed.

22453.content: They came at me from all sides, hundreds of 'em. We kept firing - Zat-Tat-Tat-Tat! "Throw the grenades," I shouted. "Mac, throw the grenades!" "He's dead," Joe said, and kept right on feeding me bullets.  Zat-Tat-Tat-Tat!  They kept falling, but they kept coming. Bullets whizzing all around me. Zot! Joe falls back with a neat red hole in his head. I thought I was done for. But I kept firing. Zat-Tat-Tat! Only one thought kept me going. Kill! Kill! For Mac, and Joe, and the rest of the guys. Kill! - a blinding flash. I wake up on a stretcher. "Did we hold?" I asked the medic. "Yes, sir," he said, and I slipped into unconsciousness.
Well, you'll soon have stories like that to tell of your own.
Sure. Be able to tell your children. Something for them to look up to. Be proud of.
I...I don't know what to say, sir. I just hope I can make it back home to tell 'em.
It's the greatest excitement in the world.
I...I never thought of it that way, sir. But you're right. It's the greatest excitement in the world. To have something to be proud of. To have something to tell.
Yes, sir. The moment of truth. When all the noise and chaos stops, and you're left with just the truth. And the truth is...I don't know, sir.

comes in with a breakfast tray: bacon and eggs, tea and toast. Come on, sit up.
