You know I didn't mind.  And it's not as if Ray's place is any better.
I'm sorry, but can we get this straight?  What is his fucking name, Ian or Ray?  What do you call him?
Okay, So you were living with Ray, and then what? You just woke up and decided to leave? Or did something happen? What's going on?

23576.content: So the minister says nice things, and then, what, we all troop outside and they bury him?
Isn't that how it is for everybody?

23597.content: Well - what do you think of my elegant new suit?
Very becoming. It looks better on you than it did on me.
I can imagine... you know, all it needed was some taking in here and letting out there - are you sure you won't want it yourself?
Quite sure. I find it just a bit too - too "Seventeenish" for me...
Oh, come now, as though you were an old lady... I'm on my way. Is there anything more you've thought of-?
Yes, I've thought of something. I've been thinking of it all the time you've been admiring yourself in that glass.
I've been thinking that you've been a bit too lavish with your money lately.
Yes. Here. I've been wanting to speak to you about it. You've been spending a great deal of money on clothes and things, and I think you ought to be more careful.
That's my job.  See you at tea time...
I'll be there. And, I'll tell you something else, I've been thinking. You've been seeing a great deal of that young woman, haven't you?
Oh, golly. And I forgot to tell you-

Well, I was sure you'd want to, of course, being his birthday, and you've been so busy these past few days, and last night I meant to tell you before you went out with the Richards - and I guess I was asleep when you got home...
Mr. Sampson's birthday. I certainly wouldn't forget that. You'd never forgive me.  As a matter of fact, I sent him a telegram myself...

23601.content: How about that new Italian place downtown? I've been wanting to try it out.
Oh.  Well.  We don't really get along. Paul and I.
Ah, I didn't know that. What's going on between you two? You've been friends for ages.

23608.content: I'm looking for Deejay Rob Gordon.
I'm Caroline Fortis from The Reader. I want to do a story on you.
Well, I've been following your career, and I think you're a fascinating figure. You're a bit of a mystery, even to your fans.
So, I was wondering if you'd be willing to do an interview with me? Maybe we could grab coffee and talk about your life, your music... everything?
Huh.  You used to come to the club? I shouldn't have let you in.  You must have only been about sixteen.

23632.content: What's that on your forehead, Max? That's a nice attention getter.
Yeah, I'm religious.  I'm not an Atheist like you!  Now, are you guys gonna arrest me, or not?
How did you start the fire this time?
Gasoline. I poured it on the curtains and lit a match. I didn't think it would spread that fast.

23678.content: It is a beautiful day.  I am merely enjoying it.
Why should I? I am not bothering anyone.

23683.content: England.  There is nothing for me here anymore.
And what do you think you will find in another land?
You're searching for a sense of identity,assistant>

23693.content: Looks like I'm going to have a very fancy party...
I thought you were going to be late-
I had no idea you were even here.
I ran into Eve on my way upstairs; she told me you were dressing.
I was just getting ready to come down and make an entrance.
Well, we started talking, she wanted to know all about Hollywood, she seemed so interested...
I'm sure she was. She's always been fascinated by the glamour of it all.
It's a pretty rare quality these days.

237.content: It ain't the money - it's the high.  The big fat floating 'what if?'  And it's way more profitable.  Nobody ever wins.  So you never have to pay out.
But a two dollar bet is cheaper than a twenty-dollar bag.
Yeah, but I ain't talking horse.  I'm talking about a five-dollar kick in the head that's a quick ticket to heaven. And the fools keep coming back for more.
I know, I know... Your people, They're my people too... We're all just a bunch of suckers...

23715.content: I can't believe you're making this up - it sounds like something out of an old Clyde Fitch play...
Clyde Fitch, thought you may not think so, was well before my time!
I've always denied the legend that you were in 'Our American Cousin' the night Lincoln was shot...

Of course it's funny - this is all too laughable to be anything else. You know what I think about this - this age obsession of yours - and now this ridiculous attempt to whip yourself up into a jealous froth because I spent ten minutes with a stage-struck kid-
You think you're so clever, don't you? Bringing up my age and trying to make me feel like some kind of relic from the past.
Thirty minutes, forty minutes! What of it?
You're just trying to provoke me, aren't you? Well, let me tell you something, I've been around a long time, and I've seen a lot of things.
Now how can you take offense at a kid trying in every way to be as much like her ideal as possible!
Ideal? Ha! You think that young girl is trying to be like me? I'm a legend, a star! She's just a... a...
A nobody! A stage-struck kid trying to make a name for herself by aping me!
This is my cue to take you in my arms and reassure you - but I'm not going to. I'm too mad-
Oh, don't be ridiculous! You're not going to comfort me? Ha! I don't need your comfort! I'm a star, I can take care of myself!

Mad! Darling, there are certain characteristics for which you are famous - on stage and off. I love you for some of them - and in spite of others. I haven't let those become too important to me. They're part of your equipment for getting along in what is laughably called out environment - you've got to keep your teeth sharp. All right. But you will not sharpen them on me - or on Eve...
(pausing, Ah, Ah, I see. So now you're trying to psychoanalyze me, are you?

She hasn't cut them yet, and you know it! So when you start judging an idealistic dreamy-eyed kid by the barroom, Benzedrine standards of this megalomaniac society - I won't have it! Eve Harrington has never by word, look, thought or suggestion indicated anything to me but her adoration for you and her happiness at our being in love! And to intimate anything else doesn't spell jealousy to me - it spells a paranoic insecurity that you should be ashamed of!
How dare you! You think you can lecture me? Me, the great Bernhardt?

2374.content: Now I want you to go back to the time you were in the woods with Lenny. Think of it like a movie. You can pause, rewind, or slow down any details you wish. Understand?
I'm standing next to Kayleigh, my hands are over her ears.
No... I'm trying to protect her from hearing the sound of the... whatever it is... that's coming from deeper in the woods.

23751.content: A little -- yes.  My interest in coming here is profession.
Alright.  In the shop you mentioned something about--
The shop. Yes. I remember. I was saying that the shop is not doing well.

23781.content: Ah Steven, it is good to see you.
I only just heard of Conor.  I came up from Catroch as soon as I could.
You're a kind man to be sure.
I thought it only proper to pay me last respects to the family.
What do you mean? I was told he was killed in the accident.
They were Steven, they were.  It's been a miracle it has.  He lasted right through and healed.  No one in the village has ever seen anything like it.  Ever.

23784.content: My future husband died in battle against the Sutherlands.
What are you saying?  I'm standing here as real as you.
You cannot be real, Conor.  You had the last rites.  No man has been cut half as bad and lived.
Live?  In less than a week you're prancing about the country like a squirrel.
I'm not dancing, I'm walking. And I'm not a squirrel, I'm a man. A man who's been to the other side and back again.
What do you mean? That I'm a spirit? A ghost?
There's rumor in the village. Some call it magic.
Magic? Ha! I'm no magician. I'm a warrior, a fighter. I've been wounded, badly wounded, but I've lived. That's no magic, that's just...
I don't know, Conor.  It's not natural.  Maybe something has touched you.
Touched me? What are you talking about? The gods? The Otherworld? I don't know what you're talking about.
Me father has taken back my hand.

23817.content: Have you taken to touring small town cemetaries, Miss Cartwright?
The ones who took the headstone.

23827.content: Juan Cid Romirez.  Chief surveyor and alchemist.

23834.content: When I was a boy a cart driven by a drunken fool crushed me.  All thought I would die or be maimed for life.  But I healed quickly. And like you I paid the price for being different.
Do you ever feel a flow, as if some- thing were pushing against you?
Does it change with me in the room?
Yes. It does. I can feel it shift and swirl around you. It's as if the air molecules themselves are being rearranged by your presence. Fascinating.
I do. I feel a deep connection to you, as if we've known each other before. It's unsettling, yet comforting at the same time.

23841.content: Why does he want to kill me?
You recall how I spoke of the push you feel and how I make it less?

It is always less with my living. Far or near.  But if I were to die the push would become stronger than ever before.  There is power in this.  And as long as you and I live, The Knight can never have it all.
You are correct. We cannot be killed. But the Knight believes we can. And he will try. He will try to take the power for himself. And if he succeeds...
How can I stop such a man?
That is the question, isn't it? You see, I have been thinking about this a great deal. And I believe I have a plan. But it will require great care and cunning.
Because the Knight is not a man to be underestimated. He is powerful and ruthless. And he will stop at nothing to get what he wants. But I believe I can help you outsmart him.

23872.content: Many of your guests have been wondering when they may be permitted to view the body. Where has it been laid out?
It hasn't been laid out, we haven't finished with the embalming. As a matter of fact, you're looking at it. The remains of Margo Channing. Sitting up. It is my last wish to be buried sitting up.
Wouldn't you feel more natural taking a bow?
You know nothing about feelings, natural or unnatural.
Then without feeling, your guests were also wondering whether the music couldn't be a shade more on the - shall we say, happier side?
The music is as I have directed. I have lived a life of discord. I have played a life of discord. Why should I not die to the sound of it?

23879.content: What are you going to tell them?  That you're protecting a man who's killed four people?

But there's more.  Wednesday someone played javelin with the cemetary curator in Felton, Delaware.  Some locals spotted two cars with D.C. plates and surprise surprise, they turn out to be registered to our own Brenna Cartwright and the ever popular Richard Taupin.

You've been a busy little beaver. Especially with that records mess up in Church Hill.  Your notes are very complete. Naturally my feelings were crushed when you didn't rush right over and tell us what you knew.  In fact, we're considering book- ing the ambulence chaser as an accessory to murder.
Ah, you're a real comedian, aren't you?
But we might just give it the 'ole college try.  What with the court back ups, it could be days before you got an arraignment. But then, I'm sure the flunk-out neice of the D.A. knows all about that.
You can't have him. He's under my protection. And I'm not going to let you take him anywhere. Not until I get some answers.
Just for laughs we raided wonder boy's house.  There was a gallon of one of the corpse's blood in his carpet.  I think it was about then I withdrew his name for humanitarian of the year.
What were you doing in Felton?
I have witnesses that can put the two of you together.
You're bluffing. You don't have any witnesses. And even if you did, I'd just deny it. You can't prove a thing.
Don't be stupid, lady.  Your neck can be sliced as fast as anyone else's.

23893.content: I thought I gave orders the regiment was to drill.
Staff sargeant detailed me to prepare firewood for the break- fast cooking.
I understand you joined up in Bremen.
I am a Major, Private.  You would do well remembering that when addressing me.

23929.content: What is it like?  Being you?
Empty.  And fear.  Fear of those that would kill you and fear of those that would love you.  It can never last, and in the end you always end up destroying both.
But you're known so much. History I'll only read about.
It's all the same.  Half lives that never go away.

23947.content: The play? All right, I guess...
"Cora." She's - still a girl of twenty?
Don't you think it's about time it became important?
I don't know. I don't know anything about it. I don't know what it's about. I don't know who's in it. I don't know anything.
I'm not. I'm just...I don't know. I don't know what to say. I don't know what to think. I don't know what to feel.
Miss Channing is ageless. Spoken like a press agent.
Ah,ah! Yes, Miss Channing is ageless. And she's always speaking like a press agent.

Spoken like an author.  Lloyd, I'm not twentyish. I am not thirtyish. Three months ago, I was forty years old. Forty. Four oh.  That slipped out, I hadn't quite made up my mind to admit it. Now I feel as if I'd suddenly taken all my clothes off...
Oh, Lloyd, You're such a card!
... as young as they want, you mean. And I'm not interested in whether thousands of people think I'm six or six hundred-
Lloyd, Lloyd, You're getting all worked up over nothing!

23951.content: Margo, as you know, i have lived in the Theater as a Trappist monk lives in his faith. I have no other world, no other life - and once in a great while I experience that moment of Revelation for which all true believers wait and pray. You were one. Jeanne Eagels another... Paula Wessely... Hayes - there are others, three or four. Eve Harrington will be among them...
I take it she read well.
It wasn't reading, it was a performance. Brilliant, vivid, something made of music and fire...
In time she'll be what you are.
You mean she'll be a Trappist monk?
Bill didn't say - but Lloyd was beside himself. He listened to his play as if someone else had written it, he said, it sounded so fresh, so new, so full of meaning...
Lloyd was beside himself. He listened to his play as if someone else had written it, he said, it sounded so fresh, so new... so full of meaning...

23959.content: Well, you're not too busy to know that the Governor hasn't signed that reprieve!
And that means Earl Williams dies tomorrow morning and makes a sucker out of us!
He's on my phone. He just called me.

23968.content: I tried to tell you right away but you started reminiscing. I'm getting married, Walter, and also getting as far away from the newspaper business as I can get! I'm through.
Get married all you want to, Hildy, but you can't quit the newspaper business.
You can't sell me that, Walter.
Who says I can't? You're a newspaper man.
That's why I'm quitting. I want to go some place where I can be a woman.
You're a woman, Hildy. You've always been a woman. You've always been a newspaper woman.

A journalist! Peeking through keyholes -- running after fire engines -- waking people up in the middle of the night to ask them if they think Hitler's going to start a war -- stealing pictures off old ladies of their daughters that got chased by apemen! I know all about reporters -- a lot of daffy buttinskies going around without a nickel in their pockets, and for what? So a million hired girls and motormen's wives will know what's going on! No, Walter, I'm through.
Hildy, Hildy, don't be like that. You're getting all worked up over nothing. You're a good reporter. You've got a good job.
Bermuda.
Bermuda? What's that got to do with anything? You're not going to Bermuda. You're going to marry me and settle down and forget about being a reporter.
Not what you'd call rich. Makes about five thousand a year.
That's not so bad. We can live on that. We can live on that and be happy. We can have a nice home and a nice life.
He's in the insurance business.
Ah, insurance! Now that's a respectable business! Not like this crazy newspaper game! You'll be a respectable married woman, Hildy, with a respectable husband in a respectable business!
It's a good, honest business, isn't it?
Of course it is! Insurance is a wonderful business! You'll be so happy, Hildy, with a husband in a good, honest business like insurance!
Well, I can, and I love it! He forgets the office when he's with me. He doesn't treat me like an errand-boy -- he treats me like a woman.
Ah, Hildy... I guess I lost you to the insurance man, didn't I?
I don't know about water buffaloes, but I know about him. He's kind and sweet and considerate. He wants a home -- and children.
Well, Hildy... I suppose I'll just have to get used to the idea of you being married to someone else...
Well, I'll give you a hint. By tomorrow they'll be calling me Mrs. Bruce Baldwin.
Ah, Hildy... Congratulations, I suppose. I'll have to get used to calling you Mrs. Baldwin, instead of Hildy Johnson.
The quicker the better. Well -- I finally got out what I came in to tell you.  So long, Walter, and better luck next time.
So long, Hildy... I mean, Mrs. Baldwin. Good luck to you, and your insurance man. I'll just sit here and get used to being an old bachelor.
Thanks...
Don't mention it. I'll just sit here and think about the good old days when you were a reporter and we had some excitement in our lives.
Well, he's waiting in the anteroom for me now.
Ah, I'll let you go then. You'd better get out there and start your new life, Mrs. Baldwin. I'll just sit here and... and... reminisce.
Oh, better not, Walter. Wouldn't do any good.
Don't you worry about me, Hildy... I mean, Mrs. Baldwin. I'll be all right. I'll just sit here and... and... think about the good old days.
Afraid? I should say not!
No, no, Hildy... I mean, Mrs. Baldwin. I'm not afraid. I'm just... just a little sad, that's all. You go on and be happy.
Better.

23969.content: Miss Channing, I can't tell you how glad I am that you arrived so late.
Well, if you'd been here to begin with, I wouldn't have dared to read at all...
... and if you'd come in the middle, I'd have stopped, I couldn't have gone on-

24007.content: How can you have any happiness after that? All through the years you'll remember that a man went to the gallows because you were too selfish to wait two hours! I tell you, Earl Williams' face will come between you on the train tonight -- and at the preacher's tomorrow -- and all the rest of your lives!
What a performance! Bravo! Don't let him fool you, Bruce -- it's only an act!
What do you mean, only an act? Haven't you got any feeling?
Well, it's either an act on your part or a miracle on Sweeney's.
I mean that Sweeney Todd is a barber and he's been in this cell for five years waiting for his appeal. And in all that time, he's never said a word against you.
All right, Hildy, I'm licked. But I'll make you and Bruce a business proposition.
Maybe you'll be. You're a smart young man. You let Hildy do this story for me and you can write out a $100,000.00 insurance policy for me. What do you say?

24018.content: You've been talking to that venomous fishwife, Addison deWitt-
- in this case, apparently, as trustworthy as the World Almanac!
You knew when you came in that the audition was over, that Eve was your understudy! Playing that childish game of cat and mouse...
Not mouse, never mouse! If anything - rat!
You have a genius for making barroom brawl out of a perfectly innocent misunderstanding at most!
That's not genius, that's just a talent for trouble! You're one to talk, you've been stirring up more trouble than a spoon in a wasp's nest!
Oh, don't play dumb with me, I've seen the way you've been looking at Eve... like a cat eyeing a bird in a gilded cage!

24030.content: I don't know. This makes me feel funny.
Why shouldn't I make Hildy my beneficiary? I've got nobody else to leave it to.
I feel I ought to take care of her.

Well, you'll take care of her. After all, if that doctor's right, I'm going to live for a long time yet. Look, Bruce, this is a debt of honor. I was a very bad husband: Hildy could have got a lot of alimony if she'd wanted to, but she wouldn't take any. She had it coming to her, but she was too independent.
I know you are. That's why I'm going to make you my beneficiary. I've got a lot of money, Bruce. I've been very successful.
Well, of course, if you put it that way.
I am putting it that way. I'm making you my beneficiary, Bruce. You're the only person I can trust. You'll take care of Hildy for me.
Good. I knew you'd see it my way. Now let's get the papers drawn up and sign them. I want to make sure Hildy's taken care of.
Gee, you almost make me feel like a heel -- coming between you.
Don't be ridiculous, Bruce. I'm doing this for Hildy's sake. I want to make sure she's all right. You'll do it for me, won't you?

24044.content: I couldn't plead insanity, because you see I'm just as sane as anybody else.
You didn't mean to kill that policeman?
Of course not. I couldn't kill anybody -- it's against everything I've ever stood for. They know it was an accident. They're not hanging me for that -- they're hanging me for my beliefs.

They're very simple. I believe in the Golden Rule. I'm not the first man to die for preaching it. But if they would only listen to it -- we could have a fine, decent world instead of this mass of hate that makes man do such cruel things.
The Golden Rule? Do unto others as you would have them do unto you?
I'd do away with the profit system and have production for use only. There's enough food and clothing and shelter for everybody if we'd use some sense.
And what about the people who don't want to work?

It's the only answer. Everything has a use and if we let it be used for its purpose, we could solve all our problems. Food was meant to be eaten, not stored away in restaurants while poor people starved; clothing was meant to be worn, not piled up in stores while people went naked. Doesn't that make sense?
It sounds like a utopian dream, Earl. But I'm not sure it's that simple. What about the people who want more than their share?

24061.content: The newspapers! Sheriff, they're the scum of modern civilization.
They're always after me for interviews.
Of course, I sort of promised them I would give out a statement when I got through here. You don't mind?
Not at all. Go ahead. I'll just sit here and mind the baby.
We'll have to satisfy them. What would you say to giving them a joint interview? I could give them some of the psychological aspects of the case and you could give them the legal aspects.
That's a great idea! I'd be happy to share the spotlight with you, especially since I'm not exactly... um... media savvy.
Yes, shaking hands. I don't take a very good picture, though.
Don't worry about that! You're a natural in front of the camera. Besides, it's not like we're going to be on the cover of Time magazine or anything.
Yes, I suppose so. It all helps.

24064.content: Let him out of here, Lieutenant.
But, Hildy, I can't. He's accused of stealing a watch. And they found the watch on him.
And who accused him? Diamond Louis! One of the worst crooks in town! Why don't you arrest Louis instead of innocent people that he frames?
Don't Hildy me! Are you going to let him out?
Alright, Alright. I'll let him go this time. But if I find out he's involved with Diamond Louis in any way...

All right. You can't. But tomorrow the Post will run the story of that roulette game on 43rd Street that your brother-in-law runs. And we'll print that you get five hundred a month for forgetting about it!
You wouldn't dare! That's a lie! My brother-in-law has a legitimate business! And I'm a honest cop! You can't blackmail me!
You can let him out on bail, can't you?
Fine! I'll let him out on bail. But this isn't over! You're not going to threaten me and get away with it! I'll make sure of it!
You'll take fifty and like it!
That's it, I'm letting him out. But mark my words, this isn't the end of this. I'll be watching you, Hildy. And you, Lieutenant.

24104.content: We got to think fast before those lying reporters get hold of this. What'll we tell 'em?
Tell 'em the party is through in this State on account of you.
Ah, Fred --  Hello... this is Hartman --
And you can tell 'em as an afterthought that I want your resignation now!
Fred, Fred, Fred... you're not listening... I said I want your resignation now!
It's a piece of paper with your name on it and a statement that you're quitting the party.

2411.content: Actually, Kayleigh, the reason I came back to town was to talk to you.
Remember when I was a kid I had all these blackouts?
Well, lately some of the memories have begun to come back and I'd kinda like to talk to you about one of them in particular. It'd be a big help.
I'm listening. What's the memory that's come back to you?
When we were kids. Your dad was making a movie. Robin Hood or something?
Robin Hood,. Yeah,. That was a crazy time. What about it?
It's just... did he... what happened in the basement?
(pausing, Wait, What are you talking about? What happened in the basement?
Kayleigh, I don't know what you're referring to.
No, but I think something really bad might've happened to us.

24110.content: I couldn't work in the city. You see, I've got my family in the country.
But you could bring 'em in here! We'll pay all your expenses.
Well, I don't know... I just don't think it would be right for 'em.
No, they wouldn't -- they'd gain one! And I guarantee that they'll graduate with highest honors!
I don't know... I just don't think it would be right for 'em.

24118.content: Oh, sure. The boss sent me over with it. Four hundred dollars, wasn't it?
Four hundred and fifty and I'll cut your throat if you try any tricks!
All right, all right. You can't blame a guy for tryin', can you?
I handed it to you. You took it.
So long, nothing! Where's Bruce Baldwin's wallet?
I don't know what you're talkin' about.

None of that innocent stuff, you double-crossing hyena! You stuck Bruce Baldwin in jail this afternoon on a phony charge that he swiped your watch, and you frisked his wallet! Now, give me that wallet or I'll stick you in jail and it won't be on any phony charge either! It'll be for life!
I didn't do nothin' like that! You're crazy!

24163.content: Where do you think you're going?
Let go o' me! I've got to get Bruce out of jail! Oh, Walter, why did you have to do this to me?
Get Bruce out of jail! How can you worry about a man who's resting comfortably in a quiet police station while this is going on? Hildy, this is war! You can't desert now!

Oh, get off that trapeze!  There's your story! Smear it all over the front page -- Earl Williams caught by the Morning Post! And take all the credit -- I covered your story for you and I got myself in a fine mess doing it -- and now I'm getting out! I know I told you that twice before today -- but this time I mean it!

You drooling idiot! What do you mean, you're getting out! There are three hundred and sixty-five days in the year one can get married -- but how many times have you got a murderer locked up in a desk? -- Once in a lifetime! Hildy, you've got the whole city by the seat of the pants!
You're not going to get away with this, you're not going to get away with this! I'm going to make sure that you pay for what you've done!

You know! You've got the brain of a pancake! That wasn't just a story you covered -- it was a revolution! Hildy! This is the greatest yarn in journalism since Livingstone discovered Stanley for the New York Herald!
You're a fine one to talk, aren't you? You've been talking for hours and you still haven't said anything! You're a regular little Napoleon!

Don't get technical at a time like this! Do you realize what you've done? You've taken a city that's been graft-ridden for forty years under the same old gang and with this yarn you're kicking 'em out and giving us a chance to have the same kind of government that New York's having under La Guardia! We'll make such monkeys out of these ward-heelers next Tuesday that nobody'll vote for them -- not even their wives!
You're a fine one to talk, aren't you? You've been talking for hours and you still haven't said anything! You're a regular little Napoleon!

Well, think it then, because it's true! We'll crucify that mob. We're going to keep Williams under cover till morning so the Post can break the story exclusive. Then we'll let the Governor in on the capture -- share the glory with him.
You're going to keep Williams under cover till morning so the Post can break the story exclusive. Then we'll let the Governor in on the capture -- share the glory with him.

You've kicked over the whole City Hall like an apple-cart. You've got the Mayor and Hartman backed against a wall. You've put one administration out and another in. This isn't a newspaper story -- it's a career! And you stand there belly-aching about whether you catch an eight o'clock train or a nine o'clock train! Still a doll-faced mugg! That's all you are.
You're a fine one to talk, aren't you? You've been talking for hours and you still haven't said anything! You're a regular little Napoleon!

Attagirl! Why, they'll be naming streets after you -- Hildy Johnson Street! There'll be statues of you in the parks, Hildy. The radio'll be after you -- the movies!  By tomorrow morning I'll betcha there's a Hildy Johnson cigar! I can see the billboards now. Light up with Hildy Johnson!
Oh, stop it! Stop it, you hear? You're making me sick! You're a regular little Napoleon!
We're going to take him over to my private office.  Where's our phone?
It's on the desk, right next to the cigar box.

24177.content: Oh -- mother -- she -- I don't know where she went.
Did you give her the money?
No, I was going to give it to her -- but she left hurriedly.
Then suppose you give me the money. Four hundred and fifty dollars.
I don't know you. You're a stranger. I don't know what you want with the money.

24184.content: I know how you feel, Bruce, but you've got to forgive her. She's only a woman, after all.
Suppose she is -- I have feelings, too! Do you know where I've been for the last couple of hours? Locked up in a police station and she didn't move to do anything about it.
And now I don't know where my mother is. She may be lost.
I'll find her, Bruce, if I have to put every detective in the city on the job. Tell you what -- go over to the Missing Persons Bureau and describe your mother. What does she look like?
She's a little woman, about fifty years old. She's got gray hair and a kind face. She was wearing a long brown coat and a hat.
That's the kind of stuff they want!

24279.content: How was that for a tight squeeze?
Don't tell me you were worried!
Worried! I was petrified. Weren't you?
Uh-uh. As long as we were in there together pitching -- they couldn't lick us. Well, it's been a lot of fun.
I mean, it's been a lot of fun. I mean, we've had some laughs. But I'll tell you one thing. I'm glad we're out of there.
We've certainly been in some swell jams.
You can say that again! But we've always managed to wriggle out of 'em. That's the main thing.
Yeah. What about the time we hid the missing heiress in the sauerkraut factory? Six scoop interviews!
Oh boy, that was a close one! I thought for sure we were goners that time! But we managed to talk our way out of it.
We sure did, but we had to go in hiding for a week.
And I had to grow a beard to disguise myself! What a mess! But we made it through, that's the important thing.
Don't remind me. That's how we happened to --

2428.content: It's my fault. I should have told you he was released a few weeks ago.
Might'a been nice.  Like this is gonna do any good. Maybe one of the frat guys has a gun.
Please, Evan. Don't even joke. He wouldn't hurt you. He's just trying to scare you away from me.
Yeah, right. Tell that to Crockett.
It's not his fault, Evan. You knew how bad he had it when we were kids.
Save it, I don't wanna hear it.
My father never laid a hand on me. It's like the prick saved it all up for Tommy.

24280.content: Sorry, Hildy. I didn't mean to be making love to another man's fiancee.
That's all right, Walter. It's as much my fault as yours.
Bruce is making the nine o'clock train. I told him you'd be on it -- unless you want to write this story yourself.
Well, if it's my last story, I'd like it to be a good one. But -- I guess I can't, Walter.
Suit yourself, kid. This isn't for me to decide. Of course, you could make a later train and still be in Albany tomorrow morning.
I'll make the nine o'clock train. I'll write this story myself.
He's going to have you the rest of his life, Hildy. Can't you give me another hour?
No, I've got to get out of here. I'll write it on the train. Good-by, Walter.
Heads, I'll stay. Tails, you'll go.

24283.content: The greatest yarn ever written by anybody. My hat's off to you, Hildy!
Thanks.
And what a way to quit. While you're still champion! That's the way to leave, Hildy!
Yeah. Only -- only I'm not leaving, Walter.
What do you mean? Bruce'll be waiting for you in Albany.
I'm not going to Albany, Walter. I'm not going anywhere. I'm going to stay right here and write the greatest yarns the world has ever seen.
Where'd you wire him?
I wired him from the telegraph office in the station. I told him I was coming to Albany and we'd make a million dollars together. But I'm not going, Walter.
Sure.
I'm not going, Walter. I'm going to stay right here and write the greatest yarns the world has ever seen.
Both jobs are open, Hildy. The paper -- and being Mrs. Walter Burns.
Ah, Walter. You're a sly one, Walter. But I'm not falling for it. I'm going to stay right here and write the greatest yarns the world has ever seen.

Sure, it was good -- it was wonderful! Only you expected it to be like other marriages. It can't be like other marriages -- we're different! We're a different world. Look at what we went through today. I wouldn't trade that for any honeymoon in the world. I bet you wouldn't, either.
Oh, Walter. You're a sly one, Walter. But I'm not falling for it.

That's what makes it romantic. Every other married couple goes away on a honeymoon and for two weeks the bride knows just where the groom is, and vice versa. But us -- you never know where I am and I'm not sure where you are. That's Romance!
Ah, Walter, you're a sly one, indeed.
Hildy, if that's what you want, all right. We'll even go to -- how about Niagara Falls?
Ah, Walter, you're a sly one... indeed.
Sure I do. And I'll tell you something else -- I'd like a baby.
Ah, Walter...  Oh, Walter. You're a sly one, indeed.
Sure, I can't last forever. I want a son I can train to take my place on this paper.
Ah, Walter... Oh, Walter. You're a sly one... indeed.
Well, if she looked like you -- Say! My brains and your looks -- that mightn't be such a bad combination.
Ha! Walter, you're a sly one... indeed.
What's the good of arguing about something that probably doesn't exist? Look, Hildy, I'm proposing to you. What do you say?
Ah, Walter... Oh, Walter... I say... YES!
I don't want to rush you. Take a couple of seconds.

2429.content: It's just... you've been acting kinda strange, you know?
I don't know. You seem... different. You make weird jokes. Your accents changed. You don't even walk the same.
Ah, I see what you mean. I think I can explain.  I've been... experimenting with my persona. Trying out different...
I can't put my finger on it, but everything's a bit off. Even the dinner tonight. It was beautiful, but...
I think I know what you're getting at. You're sensing that something's not quite... right. Like I'm not really me. Am I right?

24315.content: Karen.  I haven't been pleasant this weekend.
We've all seemed a little tense lately...
Come to think of it, I haven't been very pleasant for weeks. For that, I'm truly sorry. More than any two people I know, I don't want you and Lloyd to be angry with me...
We're never deeply angry, we just get sore. The way you do. We know you too well...
So many people - know me. I wish I did. I wish someone would tell be about me...
You're a very private person, Karen. You don't let people get close to you. You don't let them know you...

And what is that? Besides something spelled out in light bulbs, I mean. Besides something called temperament, which consists mostly of swooping about on a broomstick creaming at the top of my voice... infants behave the way I do, you know. They carry on and misbehave - they'd get drunk if they knew how - when they can't have what they want. When they feel unwanted and insecure - or unloved.

Why should he - and why should you?
Because I'm a woman. And I want to be loved. And I want to be loved by a man. Not a... a...a...
Margo. Bill is all of eight years younger than you.
That's all right. He's a kid. And I'm a woman. And I want to be loved. And I want to be loved by a man. Not a kid.
Not to you. Not to Bill.
Not to me. Not to Bill. Not to anyone. I'm a woman. And I want to be loved. And I want to be loved by a man. Not a...

24360.content: Rosehill Avenue. No roses. No hill. And it's certainly not an avenue.
You need trees for an avenue.
There was talk of planting some when we first came.

24385.content: From what would I be running?
You're always after truth - on the stage. What about off?
Then face it. I have. Since that first night - here - in the dressing room.
What are you talking about? You're not making any sense.
When you told me that whatever I became, it would be because of you-
I...I don't know what to say.
You hear all kinds of things.
I hear a lot of things, Bill. But I never thought I'd hear that.
(pausing, What's going on here? You're not making any sense. What's going on?

24411.content: After you change, if you're not busy elsewhere, we can have supper.
I'd love to! Or should I pretend I'm busy?
Let's have a minimum of pretending. I'll want to do a column about you-
I'm not enough for a paragraph.

- perhaps more than one. There's so much I want to know. I've heard your story in bits and pieces... your home in Wisconsin, your tragic marriage, your financial attachment to Margo - it started in San Francisco, didn't it?  I say - your idolatry of Margo started in San Francisco, didn't it?
Ah, you want to know all the juicy details, don't you? Alright, I'll give you the short version.
San Francisco. An oasis of civilization in the California desert. Tell me, do you share my high opinion of San Francisco?
I adore San Francisco! The city by the bay, it's a place where the heart can roam free, where the spirit can soar...
And that memorable night when Margo first dazzled you from the stage - which theater was it in San Francisco? Was it - the Shubert?
Ah, you're really digging up the past, aren't you? Alright, I'll confess...
A fine old theater, the Shubert. Full of tradition, untouched by the earthquake - so sorry - fire... by the way, what was your husband's name?
... His name was Reginald Thornton-Firbank. A man of great charm, but little character.

24421.content: - it's Addison, from start to finish, it drips with his brand of venom... taking advantage of a kid like that, twisting her words, making her say what he wanted her to say-

She's been to see me, as a matter of fact she left just before you came in - you just missed her...
She wanted to explain about her interview, wanted to apologize to someone - and didn't dare face Margo...

24445.content: You know, I've always considered myself a very clever girl. Smart. Good head on my shoulders, that sort of thing, never the wrong word at the wrong time... but then, I'd never met Addison deWitt.  I remember once I had a tooth pulled. They gave me some anaesthetic - I don't remember the name - and it affected me in a strange way. I heard myself saying things I wasn't even thinking... as if my mind were someplace outside of my body, and couldn't control what I did or said-
- and you felt just like that talking to Addison.
In a way. You find yourself trying to say what you mean, but somehow the words change - and they become his words - and suddenly you're not saying what you mean, but what he means-
Do you expect me to believe that you didn't say any of those things - that they were all Addison?
No! I don't expect you to believe anything. Except that the responsibility is mine. And the disgrace.
I see. And what do you plan to do about it?

You've really got a low opinion of me, haven't you? We'll I'll give you some pleasant news. I've been told off in no uncertain terms all over town. Miss Channing should be happy to hear that. To know how loyal her friends are - how much more loyal they are than she had a right to expect me to be...

24446.content: Tell me. How did your lunch turn out - with the man from Hollywood?

Well. I think you're painting the picture a little darker than it is, really. If nothing else - and don't underestimate him - you have a powerful friend in Addison.
I know... I know. It's just... I don't know, I feel like I'm just waiting for the other shoe to drop, you know?

24690.content: Also with the reluctant compliments of Max Fabian.

24748.content: I'm sorry it is not Glenmorangie.
As long as it is scotch.  Your white friends have abandoned you, Paul.
The United Nations are still here.

A discussion between an American Embassy official and a UN Colonel.

Watch everything? What does that mean? Are they planning something? Tell me more, Paul.

24749.content: Yes, they can photograph the epaulets on your shoulder.

'Snatch them up and put on a war crimes trial. Lock them all away forever. No political risk, and big publicity.' That's what he said.  I thought I'd better tell you.

2475.content: What do you need it for? I don't get you lately.
Duly noted. Now I'm gonna ask you for one last favor.
Shhh. I need to concentrate on the blockbuster if I'm gonna destroy it.

24760.content: What do you take me for?

It is possible - even conceivable - that you've confused me with that gang of backward children you've been playing tricks on - that you have the same contempt for me that you have for them?
I'm sure you mean something by that, Addison, but I don't know what...
Look closely, Eve, it's time you did. I am Addison deWitt. I'm nobody's fool. Least of all - yours.
Addison deWitt! I should have known better than to try to play tricks on you! You're the one person who can see right through me! I'm glad I met you, Addison!
Yes, you did. You still do.

24763.content: I think there's been a mistake. I don't have your cards.

24770.content: I have a confession. When we met...
Yes, when you worked as the nurse.
I had you transferred to Kigali.
I bribed the Minister of Health to have you transferred to Kigali.
You... you bribed the Minister of Health to have me transferred to Kigali?  Why? What did I ever do to you?
To be closer. So that I could marry you.
You...you did all that so you could marry me? (pausing, Oh my goodness...I don't know what to say.
How much did you pay the Minister?
A car?! You paid the Minister a car just to have me transferred to Kigali so you could marry me?!
It matters because...because I had no idea you felt that way about me. And I had no idea you would go to such great lengths to be with me.
A Volkswagen?! You paid the Minister a Volkswagen to have me transferred to Kigali?!  I don't know what to say...I'm speechless...

24771.content: I still don't know what you're getting at. Right now I want to take my nap. It's important that I-
- it's important right now that we talk. Killer to killer.
Not with me, you're no champion. You're stepping way up in class.
Addison, will you please say what you have to say plainly and distinctly - and then get out so I can take my nap!
I'll say it plain and distinct.
What do you mean by that?
I mean I'll say it straight out, without beating around the bush. I'll say it so you can understand it.
What have you got to do with it?
You're going to listen to what I've got to say, and you're going to listen good. You're going to listen like you never listened before.
I've got a message for you from the boss. You're to meet him at the old warehouse at midnight. He's got a proposition for you. And you're to come alone.
Belong - to you? That sound medieval - something out of an old melodrama...
Medieval? You think this is medieval? You think this is some kind of joke? Let me tell you something, this is as modern as tomorrow's newspaper.
... taken it for granted? That you and I...

24787.content: They fired a rocket at us.
Yes. Where are the Rwandan police?
I ran out of bribes. Bizimungu took them away.
That explains it. I'm sorry to tell you this but we've heard rumors the Militia are getting ready to storm the hotel.

24795.content: You know what the Scottish call it?
Ishca Baha - the water of life. I went on a tour once of the finest single malt distillery in the world. Have you ever been to Scotland?
Wonderful country, wonderful golf. I wonder - will I ever go back? What do you think?
I think you'll go back, sir. You seem like a man who appreciates the finer things in life, sir. Scotland's got a way of gettin' under your skin, sir.

24819.content: Please don't have me arrested, please! I didn't steal anything - you can search me!
How did you get in here?

I hid outside in the hall till the maid came to turn down your bed. She must've forgot something and when she went to get it, she left the door open. I sneaked in and hid till she finished. Then I just looked around - and pretty soon I was afraid somebody'd notice the lights were on so I turned them off - and then I guess, I fell asleep.
I believe you. You're not a thief. What were you looking for?
Your report? What do you mean?
About how you live, what kind of clothes you wear - what kind of perfume and books - things like that. You know the Eve Harrington clubs - that they've got in most of the girls' high schools?
I see. You're a reporter for the Eve Harrington club, and you were doing research for a story on how wealthy families like mine live. Is that right?
Ours was one of the first. Erasmus Hall. I'm the president.
I'm impressed. I didn't know that. So, you were just trying to get a scoop for your club's newsletter or something?
Lots of actresses come from Brooklyn. Barbara Stanwyck, Susan Hayward - of course, they're just movie stars.

24825.content: Hold on, I've heard this before... but I can't remember the end.
So, the guy goes to Hell and the devil says, "do you smoke?" The guy say, "yeah"... the devil say, "great cause Tuesday is cigar night, sweetest Cuban cigars you ever had."
Shit, we really need to find some gas.
Then the devil asks, "do you drink?" Guy says, "yeah"... devil say, "wonderful, Wednesday is free drinks night, best booze you ever had... all made from the finest stuff."
Guy says, this is great, but I'm still gonna get outta here... devil say oh no you can't leave... Thursday is golf day... best courses you ever played...
Guy says, this is all great but I'm still gonna get outta here... devil say oh no you can't leave... Friday is pizza day... best pizza you ever had...
I dunno... we'll ask around as we get closer. Man, I really don't want to run out of gas out here in the middle of Petticoat Junction, man.
Guy says, this is all great but I'm still gonna get outta here... devil say oh no you can't leave... Saturday is movie day... best movies you ever saw...
Guy says this is all great but I'm still gonna get outta here... devil say oh no you can't leave... Sunday is football day... best seats you ever had...

24830.content: Come on sleeping beauty, time to go to work.

Too late. You're in for life, let's move it out Private Shutterbug.
Aw, it ain't crap... it's... cute.  ...and really who are we to judge the artistic merit of the tin-can Mona Lisa?

24840.content: Hello...  ...hey Denise... what, what's wrong, did you break down?

No, nothing like that... yeah, we're gonna be a little late. We stopped for gas at this place called Capt. Spaulding's outside of Ruggsville and it turned into a whole thing, so we're kind of behind schedule.
Oh yeah, yeah I've driven by that place before. I seem to remember a crabby old bastard in a crummy clown suit running the place.

Yeah, well he's still here. I think him and Jerry are fast becoming buddies, you know Jerry... yeah, he's gotta see everything... yeah, I know... thinks there's some unsolved mystery around every corner.

Well, don't take too long, the kids are already knocking down the door demanding their sugar fix... I know, I know I forgot to mention that Halloween falls on a school night, so they're trick or treating tonight... I got the joint decked out this year, built a graveyard in the front yard like when you were a kid.
I think I know what you're talking about... yeah... I know... I know... I know... I know... I know... I know... I know... I know... I know...
Well, just promise me you'll be careful... alright, alright see ya soon... good-bye.

24860.content: Yeah, I know where that is, it's right by my house. It's Dr. Satan's tree. I can show ya.
Really, wow, so it's really a real thing.
Yeah, it's a tree. I used to play there all the time. But, you can't find it without me. Outsider can't find no deadwood.
Deadwood, is that what it's called? Cool, will you show us?
Maybe, maybe, maybe... hey, you know what word I hate?
I'm not sure, what word do you hate?
Ahah,Cone! That's a good one! So, what's the plan? Are we going to check out Dr. Satan's tree?
Any cone, yeah...  I hate that word... sounds ugly, I don't like crumple either.
Crumple? That's a new one! I think we're having a fun conversation! So, what do you say we go check out that tree? I'm curious!
I know I hate Swiss cheese, the holes make me nervous.

2487.content: Thank you.  Will you have a drink with me please?
I forgot. You never drink with...  I'll have another, please.  You despise me, don't you?
If I gave you any thought, I probably would.

But why? Oh, you object to the kind of business I do, huh? But think of all those poor refugees who must rot in this place if I didn't help them. That's not so bad. Through ways of my own I provide them with exit visas.
But think of all the poor devils who cannot meet Renault's price. I get it for them for half. Is that so parasitic?
Well, Rick, after tonight I'll be through with the whole business, and I am leaving finally this Casablanca.
I'll believe it when I see it.
Myself. I found myself much more reasonable.

24878.content: Can I help you with something?
Are you two gals all funny with each other?
I was just wondering if you two are all funny with each other?
Do you believe this fucking girl?
I think she's just joking around. Don't mind her.

2489.content: Hello, Ferrari. How's business at the Blue Parrot?
Fine, but I would like to buy your cafe.
I don't need to. I know what you're going to say.
What do you want for Sam?
I want him to leave Summer Bay alone. He's been causing a lot of trouble lately.
That's too bad. That's Casablanca's leading commodity. In refugees alone we could make a fortune if you would work with me through the black market.
You think I'm interested in getting involved in your shady dealings, Rick? I've got news for you, buddy. I'm a legitimate businessman, not some two-bit operator like you.

You think Sam's going to betray me like that? I don't think so. He's a lot of things, but a traitor he's not.
My dear Rick, when will you realize that in this world today isolationism is no longer a practical policy?

24894.content: Hey, listen to this... I think this is related to our Dr. Satan.

Yeah, in this book there's a chapter called Self Made Freaks about how people would mutilate themselves in order to work in a freak show. It mostly talks about tattooed people and wild men of Borneo and shit like that, but there is one mention of a single case where a woman was suspected of having her arms removed on purpose to become an arm-less wonder.
Yeah, so how does that fit with the story of four morons with a flat tire looking for a dead tree?
I was thinking maybe the four morons are actually the same person, Dr. Satan, and he's having some kind of identity crisis or something.
And the flat tire is like a metaphor for his emotional state or something. And the dead tree is like a symbol for his lost sense of purpose or identity.
I don't know, I'm just trying to make connections here. Maybe it's all just a bunch of random stuff and I'm reading too much into it.
Yeah. I think we need more context or something. This conversation is getting weird.
I don't know, I think we should just start over or something. This conversation is getting too weird.
You know what Jerry, who really cares at this point?
Exactly! Let's just drop it and move on. I'm freezing over here anyway.

24908.content: Hey, um...  ...what kind of animal is that?
Ain't the only thing tasty in this house.
I wonder what time it is. Seems kind of late.
What? No, I'm was worried that... I was just wondering what's taking so long.
I think we got a bit sidetracked.
That's not something to joke about.
I know. I'm sorry. I think we should get back on track.

24969.content: And I gave 'em directions out there, up by the old farm row... I figured what's the harm. Stupid kids probably going out to piss up a rope and got themselves turned around backasswards and got lost as shit.
Is that all... think real hard.
